commit_message:
context: avoid explicit TLS update with a context

It's already handled in base oslo_context class.

This change drops remaining usages of 'local' incubator module in
neutron code, so removing it from openstack-common.conf file that tracks
explicit neutron dependencies only.

Change-Id: I42211d852dfe654e5bb1d7982e2013f5c1a7582c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/11/160111/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from neutron.openstack.common import local request_id=request_id) # Allow openstack.common.log to access the context if overwrite or not hasattr(local.store, 'context'): local.store.context = self

commit_message:
Inherit exceptions correctly

Some of nova exceptions was not inherit correct base exceptions,
so could obtain wrong codes and mislead user. This patch fix it

Change-Id: I21add4c4dfbae0c325b63431cfd9510bd9b4e7aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/17/159517/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix mocking requests in test_engine_service

After commit Icf51dfd35423ac33a9126731862a90525c17306c
requests not in service's imports, so mocking
service.requests is wrong. This patch fix the situation.
Also change mocking db_api from service_software_config.

Change-Id: Ic9ac0a9ee48671716c4c1ae3517b3e5377a96b38
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/37/160737/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: @mock.patch.object(service.requests, 'put') @mock.patch.object(service.requests, 'put')

commit_message:
Remove VMware vCenter settings out of the Settings tab

- remove vCenter radio button out of "Hypervisor type" list
- remove vCenter settings block; it will be replaced by the VMware
  settings tab, see blueprint vmware-ui-settings
- remove settings fields for "VMware vCenter datastore for images
  (Glance)"; this checkbox if checked will enable Glance settings on the
  VMware settings tab
- remove `volumes_vmdk' out of statistics data definitions
- remove `volumes_vmdk' out alembic migrations
- adjust text messages and warnings
- hide VMware vCenter backend for Glance if vCenter was not enabled in
  cluster creation wizard

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint vmware-dual-hypervisor
Related-bug: 1427136
Change-Id: Ia1da7f4468b7f4f1f4c53340ebc1c582257dc39f

commit_message:
Fix for test_network_configuration

Unordered list is used in test, so accessing to list item by index
was ambiguously

Change-Id: If3b61c2c7c08dd852a388b95d2c0731714ff1596
Closes-Bug: #1427661

Cirros 0.3.3 has been out since september, we should probably roll
forward as the normal course of things. This will prime the nodepool
pump before we do it.

Change-Id: I6b6400df77fdb54ed809be696c1ffc8d957d64c3
'}]
commit_message:
prime the pump to use cirros 0.3.3.

Cirros 0.3.3 has been out since september, we should probably roll
forward as the normal course of things. This will prime the nodepool
pump before we do it.

Change-Id: I6b6400df77fdb54ed809be696c1ffc8d957d64c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/29/159429/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CIRROS_VERSIONS="0.3.2 0.3.3" for version in $CIRROS_VERSIONS; do CIRROS_ARCH=$arch VIRT_DRIVER=$driver CIRROS_VERSION=$version URLS=$(source $TOP_DIR/stackrc && echo $IMAGE_URLS) if [[ ! -z "$ALL_IMAGES" ]]; then ALL_IMAGES+=, fi ALL_IMAGES+=$URLS done
deleted_lines: CIRROS_ARCH=$arch VIRT_DRIVER=$driver URLS=$(source $TOP_DIR/stackrc && echo $IMAGE_URLS) if [[ ! -z "$ALL_IMAGES" ]]; then ALL_IMAGES+=, fi ALL_IMAGES+=$URLS

subject: Add quotation marks to parse string correclty on rhel7
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-26 08:17:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/5de60a8c20f6a83e84930fd0bd934fa3ec7a93ff', 'message': 'Adding quotation marks in order to parse string correclty on RHEL7

Problem:
On rhel8 the lvm.conf filter is generated wrongly

Root Cause:
RHEL7 seems to behave a litle differnt regards the arguments after the
"<<<" operator. To interpret the whole variable as a single string,
quotation marks around the variable are required. Ubuntu can deal
with both ways.

Resolution:
This commit adds the required quotation marks to the arguments after
the "<<<" operator

Closes-Bug #1425839

Change-Id: Ie82fcd7ef0deacbb6aaf18c5c466a5d5baf52681
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-26 08:21:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/d52cb76972fc160465d5512906e0188aca904bd2', 'message': 'Add quotation marks to parse string correclty on rhel7

Problem:
On rhel7 the lvm.conf filter is generated wrongly

Root Cause:
rhel7 seems to behave a litle differnt regards the arguments after
the "<<<" operator. To interpret the whole variable as a single
string, quotation marks around the variable are required. Ubuntu
can deal with both ways.

Resolution:
This commit adds the required quotation marks to the arguments
after the "<<<" operator

Closes-Bug #1425839

Change-Id: Ie82fcd7ef0deacbb6aaf18c5c466a5d5baf52681
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-02-26 10:18:41.000000000', 'files': ['lib/cinder_backends/lvm'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/15d40a56832baadc65fe5261f5f53ce24ad00e84', 'message': 'Add quotation marks to parse string correclty on rhel7

Problem:
On rhel7 the lvm.conf filter is generated wrongly

Root Cause:

bash-4.2 (rhel7/centos7) incorrectly splits herestrings 
when combined with IFS.  See [1] and [2]

Quoting the argument is a safe work-around

[1] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20144593/trying-to-split-a-string-into-two-variables
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1196566

Closes-Bug #1425839
Change-Id: Ie82fcd7ef0deacbb6aaf18c5c466a5d5baf52681
'}]
commit_message:
Add quotation marks to parse string correclty on rhel7

Problem:
On rhel7 the lvm.conf filter is generated wrongly

Root Cause:

bash-4.2 (rhel7/centos7) incorrectly splits herestrings 
when combined with IFS.  See [1] and [2]

Quoting the argument is a safe work-around

[1] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20144593/trying-to-split-a-string-into-two-variables
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1196566

Closes-Bug #1425839
Change-Id: Ie82fcd7ef0deacbb6aaf18c5c466a5d5baf52681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/66/159366/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IFS=';' read pv vg <<< "$pv_info" IFS='=' read label group <<< "$line"
deleted_lines: IFS=';' read pv vg <<< $pv_info IFS='=' read label group <<< $line

commit_message:
Frontend part for verification tasks change

Added a warning to the deployment confirmation dialog if
network verification wasn't performed or failed.

This is pure UI implementation which doesn't cover all the
cases. Proper implementation with backend support is needed.

Partially implements blueprint check-network-before-deployment

DocImpact
Change-Id: I8840604e50f97a07747878e1d5df2cf72dc615d5

commit_message:
Fix Ironic for Syslinux >= 5.00

Syslinux >= 5.00 pxelinux.0 binary is not "stand-alone"
anymore, it depends on some c32 modules to work correctly.
See: http://www.syslinux.org/wiki/index.php/Library_modules

Closes-Bug: #1419867
Change-Id: Ia62e980052ece3d5e2abf090b5609dea31f0d6b8

subject: Create resource cache upon creation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-17 08:24:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/84292d16d0846bce66e2fcd232a1e0c0a124e0bd', 'message': 'Create resource cache upon creation

Currently, the keystone providers ignore the output of the create command even though it provides much-needed information. This is a problem because if during the course of the puppet run that information is needed again, it must make another API request for it. This is especially problematic with the neutron providers, which instead of looking up the information via the API, look it up in the catalog. Since a keystone resource does not specify its ID upon creation, it reports it as nil, causing the neutron providers to silently fail when they need the ID of a keystone resource. This patch corrects the problem by saving the output from the create command in the @instance variable so that it is known to that resource and can be retrieved by other resources.

Alternative to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154812/

WIP - need to fix tests and add support for the rest of the providers

Change-Id: I2090f5f4a94a6ae21bf71ac0f1b33caaa602e0bc
Closes-bug: 1421573

This is especially problematic with the neutron providers, which

catalog. Since a keystone resource does not specify its ID upon
creation, it reports it as nil, causing the neutron providers to
silently fail when they need the ID of a keystone resource.

command in the @instance variable so that it is known to that
resource and can be retrieved by other resources.

commit_message:
Create resource cache upon creation

Currently, the keystone providers ignore the output of the create
command even though it provides much-needed information. This is a
problem because if during the course of the puppet run that
information is needed again, it must make another API request for it.
This is especially problematic with the neutron providers, which
instead of looking up the information via the API, look it up in the
catalog. Since a keystone resource does not specify its ID upon
creation, it reports it as nil, causing the neutron providers to
silently fail when they need the ID of a keystone resource.

This patch corrects the problem by saving the output from the create
command in the @instance variable so that it is known to that
resource and can be retrieved by other resources.

Alternative to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/154812/

Change-Id: I2090f5f4a94a6ae21bf71ac0f1b33caaa602e0bc
Closes-bug: 1421573

deleted_lines: elsif(action == 'show')

commit_message:
linux_net.metadata_accept(): IPv6 support

Even when using Neutron, Nova permits access to metadata service via
iptables firewall.  When metadata_ip configuration option contains IPv6
address, ip6tables should be used.

Add IPv6 support to linux_net.metadata_accept().  Remove -s 0.0.0.0/0
from IPv4 iptables rule because it is redundant, which allows to use
same rule syntax for IPv4 and IPv6.

Change-Id: Ibd5830150011361edcaf3b06b01590087f295d03
Closes-Bug: #1425103
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/158714/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if netaddr.IPAddress(CONF.metadata_host).version == 4: rule = '-s 0.0.0.0/0 -p tcp -m tcp --dport %s' % CONF.metadata_port if CONF.metadata_host != '127.0.0.1': rule += ' -d %s -j ACCEPT' % CONF.metadata_host else: rule += ' -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j ACCEPT' iptables_manager.ipv4['filter'].add_rule('INPUT', rule) else: rule = '-p tcp -m tcp --dport %s' % CONF.metadata_port if CONF.metadata_host != '::1': rule += ' -d %s -j ACCEPT' % CONF.metadata_host else: rule += ' -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j ACCEPT' iptables_manager.ipv6['filter'].add_rule('INPUT', rule)
deleted_lines: rule = '-s 0.0.0.0/0 -p tcp -m tcp --dport %s' % CONF.metadata_port if CONF.metadata_host != '127.0.0.1': rule += ' -d %s -j ACCEPT' % CONF.metadata_host else: rule += ' -m addrtype --dst-type LOCAL -j ACCEPT' iptables_manager.ipv4['filter'].add_rule('INPUT', rule)

commit_message:
Add api microvesion unit test case for wsgi.extends

This patch add unit test case of combination of @wsgi.Controller.api_version
and @wsgi.extends which can be a good sample for add new extension for
microversion api
Partially implements blueprint api-microversions
Change-Id: Ie1e7385d8eafaae4433c0d6bc9a4c30ba184660f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/141983/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # An extend controller to test the combination test cases of # wsgi.Controller.api_version and wsgi.extends class MicroversionsController3Extend(wsgi.Controller): @wsgi.Controller.api_version("2.1", "2.2") @wsgi.extends def create(self, req, resp_obj, body): resp_obj.obj['param_ext'] = 'create_val1_ext' @wsgi.Controller.api_version("2.3") # noqa @wsgi.extends def create(self, req, resp_obj, body): resp_obj.obj['param_ext2'] = 'create_val2_ext' controller = MicroversionsController3Extend() extension = extensions.ControllerExtension(self, 'microversions3', controller) return [extension]
deleted_lines: return []

commit_message:
Prepare token clients for migration to tempest-lib

Prepare token clients for migration to tempest-lib together
with auth.py. Removing all the dependencies from CONF, and thus
introducing new parameters in auth providers as well.

Change-Id: I7c03b07ec1b9268fea68125b5bbfa8fe0ff75b71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/67/159267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.auth_provider = get_auth_provider(self.credentials) def get_auth_provider_class(credentials): if isinstance(credentials, auth.KeystoneV3Credentials): return auth.KeystoneV3AuthProvider, CONF.identity.uri_v3 else: return auth.KeystoneV2AuthProvider, CONF.identity.uri def get_auth_provider(credentials): default_params = { 'disable_ssl_certificate_validation': CONF.identity.disable_ssl_certificate_validation, 'ca_certs': CONF.identity.ca_certificates_file, 'trace_requests': CONF.debug.trace_requests } if credentials is None: raise exceptions.InvalidCredentials( 'Credentials must be specified') auth_provider_class, auth_url = get_auth_provider_class( credentials, **default_params) return auth_provider_class(credentials, auth_url)
deleted_lines: self.auth_provider = self.get_auth_provider(self.credentials) @classmethod def get_auth_provider_class(cls, credentials): if isinstance(credentials, auth.KeystoneV3Credentials): return auth.KeystoneV3AuthProvider, CONF.identity.uri_v3 else: return auth.KeystoneV2AuthProvider, CONF.identity.uri def get_auth_provider(self, credentials): if credentials is None: raise exceptions.InvalidCredentials( 'Credentials must be specified') auth_provider_class, auth_url = self.get_auth_provider_class( credentials) return auth_provider_class(credentials, auth_url)

commit_message:
Enforce in REST API layer on v2.1 api remote consoles

This patch moves policy checking to REST API layer for
remote consoles, and added unit tests.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-policy

commit_message:
Cover the basic resource API with gabbi tests

These tests cover the ResourceController and ResourcesController
classes. This is not to suggest that they mean those API endpoints
are fully tested but rather than the code is used. Edge cases and
issues with authorization will need to be handled in subsequent
patchsets.

Note that several of the included tests are flagged as being
expected to fail. Where this is the case there are links to
launchpad bugs.

Missing from this is removal of the corresponding pre-existing
WebTest tests.

Change-Id: Idecec1c97da327b599901fd458ea3a593f5967f7

commit_message:
Update to Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

* image/ubuntu:
  - make sure puppet agent is not started during OS boot
  - catch up the new ruby packages naming convention
  - don't install Mellanox related packages (should be reverted
    after rebuilding those packages for Ubuntu 14.04)
* requirements-deb.txt:
  - adapt to the packages' names changes (guestmount -> libguestfs-tools)
  - use the default version of ruby (ruby 1.8 is not available any more),
    catch up the new ruby packages naming convention.
  - dhcp-checker is gone, long live nailgun-net-checker.
  - temporarily skip Mellanox related packages (until they get rebuild
    for Ubuntu 14.04)
* config.mk:
  - use the new OBS APT repository
* packages/deb/specs:
  - nailgun-agent, fencing-agent: depend on ohai, so the custom ruby-ohai
    package (which actually contains the identical code) is not required
    any more
  - temporarily remove nailgun-agent and fencing-agent from requiremets-deb.txt

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty
Change-Id: I4300b892c1fbb8d1dfa8bdd18815d56bcabe324d

[FIXUP] image/ubuntu: don't install Mellanox packages

Change-Id: I02fd5e715bc3a29f35ae84dd1fb01660b77640c8

commit_message:
Fix bad interaction between @wsgi.extends and @wsgi.api_version

Fixes possible bad interaction when both wsgi.extends and wsgi.api_version
decorators are used on the same method. Adds test cases to verify it works now

Partially implements blueprint api-microversions

Change-Id: Ib72d0257fc943d7afd25e1cef46fafff657620b5

commit_message:
Test broker connection in functional tests

We need to ensure that the broker works before each tests
at least for rabbit and qpid otherwise the driver will retry to connect
to the broker forever.

Change-Id: I4b93a3c8e010408041bff12665c8a69b6847fd84

commit_message:
Enforce in REST API layer on v2.1 shelve api

This patch moves policy checking to REST API layer
for shelve/shelve_offload/unshelve, and added unit tests.

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-policy
DocImpact
Change-Id: I41c50de3aa9f39340cd3913bdd0fc14d21d64aa7

added_lines: class TestDeploymentAttributesSerialization61(BaseDeploymentSerializer61): def setUp(self): super(TestDeploymentAttributesSerialization61, self).setUp() self.cluster = self.create_env('ha_compact') objects.NodeCollection.prepare_for_deployment(self.env.nodes) self.serializer = DeploymentHASerializer61(self.cluster) def test_serialize_workloads_collector_user(self): oswl_user = self.serializer.get_common_attrs( self.env.clusters[0] )['workloads_collector'] self.assertEqual(set(oswl_user.keys()), set(['username', 'enabled', 'password', 'type', 'tenant'])) self.assertEqual(oswl_user['username'], 'workloads_collector') self.assertEqual(oswl_user['enabled'], True) self.assertEqual(len(oswl_user['password']), 8) self.assertEqual(oswl_user['type'], 'hidden') self.assertEqual(oswl_user['tenant'], 'services')

commit_message:
Fix SessionClient error when endpoint=None

If there is no endpoint, SessionClient failes because of
required endpoint in __init__ args. Also this patch adds
tests for SessionClient.

Change-Id: I0475698fe34d4acf0d0187fb87d02781bce6f74a
Closes-bug: #1427310
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/31/160431/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import mockfrom heatclient.tests import test_shell from keystoneclient.auth.identity import v2 as ks_v2_auth from keystoneclient import session class SessionClientTest(test_shell.TestCase, testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(SessionClientTest, self).setUp() self.register_keystone_auth_fixture() self.auth_session = session.Session() self.auth_session.request = mock.Mock() self.auth_plugin = ks_v2_auth.Password(test_shell.V2_URL, 'xx', 'xx') def test_session_raw_request(self): self.auth_session.request.return_value = fakes.FakeHTTPResponse( 200, 'OK', {'content-type': 'application/octet-stream'}, '') client = http.SessionClient(session=self.auth_session, auth=self.auth_plugin) resp = client.raw_request(method='GET', url='') self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) self.assertEqual('', ''.join([x for x in resp.content])) def test_session_json_request(self): self.auth_session.request.return_value = fakes.FakeHTTPResponse( 200, 'OK', {'content-type': 'application/json'}, '{}') client = http.SessionClient(session=self.auth_session, auth=self.auth_plugin) resp, body = client.json_request('GET', '') self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) self.assertEqual({}, body) def test_404_error_response(self): self.auth_session.request.return_value = fakes.FakeHTTPResponse( 404, 'OK', {'content-type': 'application/octet-stream'}, '') client = http.SessionClient(session=self.auth_session, auth=self.auth_plugin) e = self.assertRaises(exc.HTTPNotFound, client.raw_request, 'GET', '') # Assert that the raised exception can be converted to string self.assertIsNotNone(str(e))

commit_message:
correct column types in events

in migration script, we incorrectly set string traits to Text and
float traits to Float. this fixes it so they point to String(255)
and Float(53) as they did originally

Change-Id: Ie06781a42ec7384d88bea8498140e52f109e9f7e
Closes-Bug: #1423710

commit_message:
Avoid DetachedInstanceError after session rollback

In some cases this exception is thrown while accessing Agent
object from logging statement after a transaction was rolled back.
There is a unit test that covers thsi code patch, but the issue
is not reproducible with sqlite.
Just avoid accessing db object after session had been closed.

Change-Id: Iff6b72156b08f177bd0c71f6ba93d3bf46c82fa4
Closes-Bug: #1424578

Add error checks to provider net and subnet creation

Error checks are added to detect provider network and subnet
creation.

Closes-Bug: #1423766

implement bp add separate role for cinder-vmware

Add separate role for cinder with vmdk backend for
vmware-related clouds.

Implements: blueprint cinder-vmdk-role

subject: Fixes interfaces template identification issue
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-18 11:51:34.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/network/test_network_info.py', 'nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_xenapi.py', 'nova/virt/interfaces.template', 'nova/virt/netutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/de1b33d13cdcd7dd1468275a1da8886da469e480', 'message': 'Fixes interfaces template identification issue

When using networks without DHCP enabled and "flat_injected" set to True,
the interfaces template is injected in the associated instances or
included in the config drive metadata.

The template includes the interface name, based on a progressive numbering
(eth0, eth1, etc). In case of multiple nics, there's no clear way to
identify the interfaces in the guest OS if the actual interface naming
differs, this is especially valid for Windows instances.

Since the MAC address (hardware address) assigned to each vNIC identifies
uniquely the interface, providing the mac address during the template
generation solves the issue.

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/network/test_network_info.py
        nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_xenapi.py

Change-Id: Id82db6d83caedf0e95f882d909b77ea9b98b2547
Closes-Bug: #1400080
(cherry-pick from commit 577174b025af9513aaba572d6965f9b0e0d1b3c1)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes interfaces template identification issue

When using networks without DHCP enabled and "flat_injected" set to True,
the interfaces template is injected in the associated instances or
included in the config drive metadata.

The template includes the interface name, based on a progressive numbering
(eth0, eth1, etc). In case of multiple nics, there's no clear way to
identify the interfaces in the guest OS if the actual interface naming
differs, this is especially valid for Windows instances.

Since the MAC address (hardware address) assigned to each vNIC identifies
uniquely the interface, providing the mac address during the template
generation solves the issue.

Conflicts:
        nova/tests/unit/network/test_network_info.py
        nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_xenapi.py

Change-Id: Id82db6d83caedf0e95f882d909b77ea9b98b2547
Closes-Bug: #1400080
(cherry-pick from commit 577174b025af9513aaba572d6965f9b0e0d1b3c1)

commit_message:
remove event_types ordering assumption

test occassionally fails because it assumes event_types have an
order when returned. this is not true, so remove this assumption.

Change-Id: I6d5ba033b373643a13a214f5efd4ba366e6ae147
Closes-Bug: #1427367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/89/160489/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for i in range(0, 5): self.assertTrue('event_%d' % i in e_types)
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(['event_%d' % i for i in range(0, 5)], e_types)

commit_message:
Convert nova.compute.* to use instance dot notation

nova.compute.* should use instance objects with the field access
dot notation everywhere. Essentially we use instance.key instead
of instance['key']. Needed to rework some of the test cases to get
them working. This change depends on:
Ib2288f2e6dadde9b31946a6f353111d8b4779a0b

Change-Id: I17914226e412e66b3de7681799dcf1690f590683
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/14/157914/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fault_obj.instance_uuid = instance.uuid info_cache = instance.info_cache or {}
deleted_lines: fault_obj.instance_uuid = instance['uuid'] info_cache = instance['info_cache'] or {}

so the custom ruby-ohai package (which actually contains the identical code)

Change-Id: I00ee65a98851fbb209076b093034c77867f7a738

commit_message:
nailgun-agent, fencing-agent: depend on ohai

so the custom ruby-ohai package (which actually contains the identical code)
is not necessary any more

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: I00ee65a98851fbb209076b093034c77867f7a738
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/80/160180/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Depends: ohai (<< 7),
deleted_lines: Depends: ruby-ohai (<7),

subject: Reuse OpenStack packages built for Ubuntu 12.04 with Ubuntu 14.04
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-25 12:01:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main/commit/c4b40ee9b1976001830bc4cea1b39d9de5dd5780', 'message': 'Reuse OpenStack packages built for Ubuntu 12.04 with Ubuntu 14.04

* Convince APT to use the OSCI repositories intended for Ubuntu 12.04.

* Use the upstream versions of the following non-OpenStack packages:
  bash, lvm2, nmap, atop, dnsmasq, pacemaker, corosync, etc
  These were taken from Ubuntu 14.04 and recompiled for 12.04 (and
  are going to conflict with the upstream versions).

* Use the upstream versions of the following pythonic packages:
  httplib2, urllib3, warlock, webob, python-openssl, python-crypto,
  python-mock, networkx, etc.

* Use the upstream versions of qemu, mcollective, ceph, as Mirantis
  versions of those packages can not be installed in Ubuntu 14.04.
  Also many of these packages have been trivially backported from
  Ubuntu 14.04

Note: this patch should be reverted after rebuilding OpenStack packages
in Ubuntu 14.04 environment.

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: Id17682140af55d164734076322679702ce996b70

'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2015-02-04 13:05:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main/commit/91ec304be55aa033a08951d3d9e9d54d39965a6b', 'message': 'Reuse OpenStack packages built for Ubuntu 12.04 with Ubuntu 14.04

* Convince APT to use the OSCI repositories intended for Ubuntu 12.04.

* Use the upstream versions of the following non-OpenStack packages:
  bash, lvm2, nmap, atop, dnsmasq, pacemaker, corosync, etc
  These were taken from Ubuntu 14.04 and recompiled for 12.04 (and
  are going to conflict with the upstream versions).

* Use the upstream versions of the following pythonic packages:
  httplib2, urllib3, warlock, webob, python-openssl, python-crypto,
  python-mock, networkx, etc.

* Use the upstream versions of qemu, mcollective, ceph, as Mirantis
  versions of those packages can not be installed in Ubuntu 14.04.
  Also many of these packages have been trivially backported from
  Ubuntu 14.04

Note: this patch should be reverted after rebuilding OpenStack packages
in Ubuntu 14.04 environment.

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: Id17682140af55d164734076322679702ce996b70

commit_message:
Reuse OpenStack packages built for Ubuntu 12.04 with Ubuntu 14.04

* Convince APT to use the OSCI repositories intended for Ubuntu 12.04.

* Use the upstream versions of the following non-OpenStack packages:
  bash, lvm2, nmap, atop, dnsmasq, pacemaker, corosync, etc
  These were taken from Ubuntu 14.04 and recompiled for 12.04 (and
  are going to conflict with the upstream versions).

* Use the upstream versions of the following pythonic packages:
  httplib2, urllib3, warlock, webob, python-openssl, python-crypto,
  python-mock, networkx, etc.

* Use the upstream versions of qemu, mcollective, ceph, as Mirantis
  versions of those packages can not be installed in Ubuntu 14.04.
  Also many of these packages have been trivially backported from
  Ubuntu 14.04

Note: this patch should be reverted after rebuilding OpenStack packages
in Ubuntu 14.04 environment.

blueprint support-ubuntu-trusty

Change-Id: Id17682140af55d164734076322679702ce996b70

commit_message:
[IBP] move udev rules manipulating out of cloud-init

We need to create udev rules prior the first boot. It's significally
easier to inject files and less magic required.

Change-Id: Iaa4dddad0efe5ac41f6b1284a8c4aa85066e39a9
Closes-Bug: #1420885
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/82/155782/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: #Add static udev rules cloud-init-per instance udev_persistent_net_disable_generator /bin/sh -c 'echo | tee /etc/udev/rules.d/75-persistent-net-generator.rules' cloud-init-per instance udev_persistent_net2 /bin/sh -c 'echo {{ common.udevrules }} | tr " " "\n" | tr "[:upper:]" "[:lower:]" | sed -e "s/udevrules=//g" -e "s/,/\n/g" | sed -e "s/^/SUBSYSTEM==\"net\",\ ACTION==\"add\",\ DRIVERS==\"?*\",\ ATTR{address}==\"/g" -e "s/_/\",\ ATTR{type}==\"1\",\ KERNEL==\"eth*\",\ NAME=\"/g" -e "s/$/\"/g" | tee /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules' cloud-init-per instance udev_persistent_net3 udevadm control --reload-rules #NOTE(agordeev): udevadm trigger will rename NIC only if network service is stopped. cloud-init-per instance udev_persistent_net4 udevadm trigger --attr-match=subsystem=net #NOTE(agordeev): udev is so asynchronous. Always use settle. cloud-init-per instance udev_persistent_net_settle udevadm settle --quiet

commit_message:
Remove extra fs making in fuel-agent

Currently, we create FS wherever they are set even if we then put an
image on that device (image is to contain a valid FS).
Moreover, It can consume significant amount of time. Let's avoid that.

Change-Id: Id45e35d18ec48b308aec2415c65de8137b745e84
Closes-Bug: #1412759
(cherry picked from commit 677486059c8d5d621287cabbe7023014d3eb392e)

subject: Allow coordinator non-string options and use them
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-13 02:11:49.000000000', 'files': ['tooz/drivers/zake.py', 'tooz/coordination.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tooz/commit/60bf3af5879e5f5df1a6be69f98e714ed9c17212', 'message': 'Allow coordinator non-string options and use them

To allow the zake driver to use a pre-existing storage
backend (for example, shared with a taskflow test that
also uses zake) we need a way to provide non-query-string
options and to get those options to the zake driver for
usage.

This approach allows the `get_coordinator` function
to take **kwargs and have those take precedence over
the options found with the same name in the urls query
string (and merge those together to form the coordinators
option dictionary that exists already).

Change-Id: Ibc745927eccac050992227410cca393d956f8c44
'}]
commit_message:
Allow coordinator non-string options and use them

To allow the zake driver to use a pre-existing storage
backend (for example, shared with a taskflow test that
also uses zake) we need a way to provide non-query-string
options and to get those options to the zake driver for
usage.

This approach allows the `get_coordinator` function
to take **kwargs and have those take precedence over
the options found with the same name in the urls query
string (and merge those together to form the coordinators
option dictionary that exists already).

Change-Id: Ibc745927eccac050992227410cca393d956f8c44
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/02/155602/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_coordinator(backend_url, member_id, **kwargs): :param kwargs: additional coordinator options (these take precedence over options of the **same** name found in the ``backend_url`` arguments query string) if kwargs: options = {} for (k, v) in six.iteritems(kwargs): options[k] = [v] for (k, v) in six.iteritems(parsed_qs): if k not in options: options[k] = v else: options = parsed_qs invoke_args=(member_id, parsed_url, options)).driver
deleted_lines: def get_coordinator(backend_url, member_id): invoke_args=(member_id, parsed_url, parsed_qs)).driver

commit_message:
Add fixed_key parameter

fixed_key is a generated HEX string
This value will be used for encrypting/decrypting
volumes created by Cinder (cinder-volume) and
accesing it with Nova (nova-compute)

Partial-Bug: #1420849

Change-Id: If039678b6c69d54ebdd203fc2ed247b3cca103cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/79/158579/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fixed_key: generator: "hexstring" generator_arg: "64"

commit_message:
archive_policy: have a sane default list of agg methods

The current default is to include ALL aggregation methods, which
includes a hundred of percentile methods. This patch adds a new option
to set the default value to something smarter, and add support for +/-
syntax over this default list.

Change-Id: Id7eb07f08713f966aa463df0111fb3d176428c40

commit_message:
Astute provision improvements

- run provision in chunks, like deploy
- do not stop if some nodes failed to provision
  by default 10% of nodes can fail

Change-Id: I061338ca6269eb5967858adb5276063238c757d1
Blueprint: 100-nodes-support
Related-bug: #1383498
Related-bug: #1386861
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/77/132077/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: failed_nodes = [] not_provisioned_nodes = [] provisioned_nodes = [] not_rebooted_nodes = [] result_msg = {'nodes' => []} max_failed_nodes = Astute.config[:ALLOWED_FAILED_NODES_PERCENT] / 100.0 * nodes.count Astute.logger.info "Max nodes allowed to fail: #{max_failed_nodes}." nodes.each_slice(Astute.config[:MAX_NODES_PER_CALL]) do |piece| failed = provision_piece(reporter, task_id, engine_attrs, piece, cobbler) failed_nodes += failed if failed_nodes.present? and failed_nodes.count > max_failed_nodes break end provisioned, not_provisioned = watch_provision_progress(reporter, task_id, piece) provisioned_nodes += provisioned not_provisioned_nodes += not_provisioned if not_provisioned_nodes.present? and \ failed_nodes.count + not_provisioned_nodes.count > max_failed_nodes break end not_rebooted_nodes = nodes.select{|node| failed_nodes.include? node[:name]} not_rebooted_nodes = not_rebooted_nodes.map do |n| { 'uid' => n, 'error_msg' => "node did not reboot.", 'progress' => 100, 'error_type' => 'provision' } end if not_provisioned_nodes.present? uids = not_provisioned_nodes.map {|n| n["uid"] } names = nodes.select{|node| uids.include? node["uid"]} names = names.map{|n| n["name"]} Astute.logger.info "Not provisioned nodes: #{names}." unlock_nodes_discovery(reporter, task_id="", names, nodes) end result_msg["nodes"] = provisioned_nodes + not_provisioned_nodes + not_rebooted_nodes if failed_nodes.count + not_provisioned_nodes.count > max_failed_nodes result_msg.merge!({ 'status' => 'error', 'error' => 'Error occured while provisioning', 'progress' => 100}) else result_msg.reverse_merge!({'status' => 'ready', 'progress' => 100}) end reporter.report(result_msg) end def provision_piece(reporter, task_id, engine_attrs, nodes, cobbler) provision_method = engine_attrs['provision_method'] || 'cobbler' # if provision_method is 'image', we do not need to immediately # reboot nodes. instead, we need to run image based provisioning # process and then reboot nodes # TODO(kozhukalov): do not forget about execute_shell_command timeout which is 3600 # watch_provision_progress has PROVISIONING_TIMEOUT + 3600 is much longer than PROVISIONING_TIMEOUT if provision_method == 'image' # disabling pxe boot cobbler.netboot_nodes(nodes, false) image_provision(reporter, task_id, nodes) end # TODO(vsharshov): maybe we should reboot nodes using mco or ssh instead of Cobbler reboot_events = cobbler.reboot_nodes(nodes) not_rebooted_nodes = cobbler.check_reboot_nodes(reboot_events) # control reboot for nodes which still in bootstrap state control_reboot_using_ssh(reporter, task_id, nodes) return not_rebooted_nodes Astute.logger.info "All nodes #{nodes.join(',')}." provisioned_nodes = [] not_provisioned = [] not_provisioned = nodes_not_booted.map do |n| provisioned_nodes << {'uid' => uid, 'progress' => 100, 'status' => 'provisioned'} return provisioned_nodes, not_provisioned
deleted_lines: provision_method = engine_attrs['provision_method'] || 'cobbler' # if provision_method is 'image', we do not need to immediately # reboot nodes. instead, we need to run image based provisioning # process and then reboot nodes # TODO(kozhukalov): do not forget about execute_shell_command timeout which is 3600 # watch_provision_progress has PROVISIONING_TIMEOUT + 3600 is much longer than PROVISIONING_TIMEOUT if provision_method == 'image' # disabling pxe boot cobbler.netboot_nodes(nodes, false) image_provision(reporter, task_id, nodes) # TODO(vsharshov): maybe we should reboot nodes using mco or ssh instead of Cobbler reboot_events = cobbler.reboot_nodes(nodes) failed_nodes = cobbler.check_reboot_nodes(reboot_events) # control reboot for nodes which still in bootstrap state control_reboot_using_ssh(reporter, task_id, nodes) err_msg = "Nodes failed to reboot: #{failed_nodes.inspect}" Astute.logger.error(err_msg) reporter.report({ 'error' => err_msg, 'progress' => 100}) raise FailedToRebootNodesError.new(err_msg) watch_provision_progress(reporter, task_id, nodes) result_msg = {'nodes' => []} nodes_progress = nodes_not_booted.map do |n| result_msg.merge!({ 'status' => 'error', 'error' => 'Timeout of provisioning is exceeded', 'progress' => 100}) result_msg['nodes'] += nodes_progress result_msg['nodes'] << {'uid' => uid, 'progress' => 100, 'status' => 'provisioned'} # If there was no errors, then set status to ready result_msg.reverse_merge!({'status' => 'ready', 'progress' => 100}) proxy_reporter.report(result_msg) result_msg

commit_message:
Separate tasks for openstack::network deployment

Implements separate tasks for controller and compute nodes to
deploy openstack::network.

Change-Id: Ia3937047c2f726c8532f78cd02452f14668dcf1c
Related-Blueprint: fuel-library-modularization

ipsort(values($controller_internal_addresses)) $rabbit_hash = hiera('rabbit_hash', {}) $internal_address = hiera('internal_address') $service_endpoint = hiera('management_vip') $nova_hash = fqdn_rotate($controller_nodes) } $amqp_port = '5673' $amqp_hosts = inline_template("<%= @amqp_nodes.map {|x| x + ':' + @amqp_port}.join ',' %>") if $use_neutron { include l23network::l2 $neutron_nsx_config['metadata']['enabled'] { $use_vmware_nsx = true } } else { $floating_ips_range = hiera('floating_network_range') $neutron_config = {} $novanetwork_params = hiera('novanetwork_parameters') $network_size = $novanetwork_params['network_size'] $num_networks = $novanetwork_params['num_networks'] $vlan_start = $novanetwork_params['vlan_start'] $network_provider = 'nova' } $network_manager = "nova.network.manager.${novanetwork_params['network_manager']}" $network_config = { 'vlan_start' => $vlan_start, } $keystone_admin_tenant = $access_hash[tenant] $openstack_version = { 'keystone' => 'installed', 'glance' => 'installed', 'horizon' => 'installed', 'nova' => 'installed', 'novncproxy' => 'installed', 'cinder' => 'installed', } ######## [Nova|Neutron] Network ######## if $network_manager !~ /VlanManager$/ and $network_config { $config_overrides = delete($network_config, 'vlan_start') } else { $config_overrides = $network_config } if $network_provider == 'neutron' { $neutron_db_uri = "mysql://${neutron_db_user}:${neutron_db_password}@${db_host}/${neutron_db_dbname}?&read_timeout=60" $neutron_server = true # We need to restart nova-api after making changes via nova_config # so we need to declare the service and notify it include ::nova::params service { 'nova-api': ensure => 'running', name => $::nova::params::api_service_name, } Nova_config<| |> ~> Service['nova-api'] # FIXME(xarses) Nearly everything between here and the class # should be moved into osnaily or nailgun but will stay here # in the interum. $neutron_settings = hiera('quantum_settings') $nets = $neutron_settings['predefined_networks'] if $primary_controller { Service<| title == 'neutron-server' |> -> Openstack::Network::Create_network <||> Service<| title == 'neutron-server' |> -> Openstack::Network::Create_router <||> openstack::network::create_network{'net04': netdata => $nets['net04'] } -> openstack::network::create_network{'net04_ext': netdata => $nets['net04_ext'] } -> openstack::network::create_router{'router04': internal_network => 'net04', external_network => 'net04_ext', tenant_name => $keystone_admin_tenant } } nova_config { 'DEFAULT/default_floating_pool': value => 'net04_ext' } $pnets = $neutron_settings['L2']['phys_nets'] if $pnets['physnet1'] { $physnet1 = "physnet1:${pnets['physnet1']['bridge']}" notify{ $physnet1:} } if $pnets['physnet2'] { $physnet2 = "physnet2:${pnets['physnet2']['bridge']}" notify{ $physnet2:} if $pnets['physnet2']['vlan_range'] { $vlan_range = ["physnet2:${pnets['physnet2']['vlan_range']}"] $fallback = split($pnets['physnet2']['vlan_range'], ':') Openstack::Network::Create_network { tenant_name => $keystone_admin_tenant, fallback_segment_id => $fallback[1] } notify{ $vlan_range:} } } else { $vlan_range = [] } if $physnet1 and $physnet2 { $bridge_mappings = [$physnet1, $physnet2] } elsif $physnet1 { $bridge_mappings = [$physnet1] } elsif $physnet2 { $bridge_mappings = [$physnet2] } else { $bridge_mappings = [] } if $neutron_settings['L2']['tunnel_id_ranges'] { $enable_tunneling = true $tunnel_id_ranges = [$neutron_settings['L2']['tunnel_id_ranges']] $alt_fallback = split($neutron_settings['L2']['tunnel_id_ranges'], ':') Openstack::Network::Create_network { tenant_name => $keystone_admin_tenant, fallback_segment_id => $alt_fallback[0] } } else { $enable_tunneling = false $tunnel_id_ranges = [] } notify{ $tunnel_id_ranges:} if $neutron_settings['L2']['mechanism_drivers'] { $mechanism_drivers = split($neutron_settings['L2']['mechanism_drivers'], ',') } else { $mechanism_drivers = ['openvswitch'] } if $neutron_settings['L2']['provider'] == 'ovs' { $core_plugin = 'openvswitch' $service_plugins = ['router', 'firewall', 'metering'] $agent = 'ovs' } elsif $neutron_settings['L2']['provider'] == 'nsx' { $core_plugin = 'vmware' } else { $core_plugin = 'neutron.plugins.ml2.plugin.Ml2Plugin' $service_plugins = ['neutron.services.l3_router.l3_router_plugin.L3RouterPlugin','neutron.services.metering.metering_plugin.MeteringPlugin'] $agent = 'ml2-ovs' } } else { $neutron_server = false $neutron_db_uri = undef # Stubs for nova::network file { '/etc/nova/nova.conf': ensure => 'present', } } class { 'openstack::network': network_provider => $network_provider, agents => [$agent, 'metadata', 'dhcp', 'l3'], ha_agents => $primary_controller ? {true => 'primary', default => 'slave'}, verbose => true, debug => hiera('debug', true), use_syslog => hiera('use_syslog', true), $mechanism_drivers, local_ip => $internal_address, bridge_mappings => $bridge_mappings, network_vlan_ranges => $vlan_range, enable_tunneling => $enable_tunneling, tunnel_id_ranges => commit_message:
Add Heat OSTF test thats check suspend/resume/check actions

Already there is OSTF test that checks basic stack actions
(create, delete, get resourse list). Now was added
one more Heat OSTF test that checks advanced stack actions:
suspend, resume and check.

Change-Id: I946a6623cf023e148c16bc58e0c5ce7638a91b06
Closes-Bug: #1426049
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/55/159555/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_advanced_actions(self): """Advanced stack actions: suspend, resume and check. Target component: Heat Scenario: 1. Create a stack. 2. Wait until the stack status will change to 'CREATE_COMPLETE'. 3. Call stack suspend action. 4. Wait until the stack status will change to 'SUSPEND_COMPLETE'. 5. Call stack resume action. 6. Wail until the stack status will change to 'RESUME_COMPLETE'. 7. Call stack check action. 8. Wail until the stack status will change to 'CHECK_COMPLETE'. 9. Delete the stack and wait for the stack to be deleted. Duration: 650 s. """ self.check_image_exists() parameters = { "InstanceType": self.testvm_flavor.name, "ImageId": self.config.compute.image_name } if "neutron" in self.config.network.network_provider: parameters["network"] = self.private_net template = self._load_template( "heat_create_neutron_stack_template.yaml") else: template = self._load_template( "heat_create_nova_stack_template.yaml") fail_msg = "Stack was not created properly." # create stack stack = self.verify(20, self._create_stack, 1, fail_msg, "stack creation", self.heat_client, template, parameters=parameters) self.verify(300, self._wait_for_stack_status, 2, fail_msg, "stack status becoming 'CREATE_COMPLETE'", stack.id, 'CREATE_COMPLETE') instances = self._get_stack_instances("ost1-test_heat") if not instances: self.fail("Failed step: 2 Instance for the {0} stack " "was not created.".format(stack.stack_name)) # suspend stack fail_msg = "Stack suspend failed" self.verify(10, self.heat_client.actions.suspend, 3, fail_msg, "executing suspend stack action", stack.id) self.verify(60, self._wait_for_stack_status, 4, fail_msg, "stack status becoming 'SUSPEND_COMPLETE'", stack.id, 'SUSPEND_COMPLETE') fail_msg = "Server is not in SUSPENDED status." inst_status = self.compute_client.servers.get(instances[0].id).status self.verify_response_body_content(inst_status, 'SUSPENDED', fail_msg, 4) # resume stack fail_msg = "Stack resume failed" self.verify(10, self.heat_client.actions.resume, 5, fail_msg, "executing resume stack action", stack.id) self.verify(60, self._wait_for_stack_status, 6, fail_msg, "stack status becoming 'RESUME_COMPLETE'", stack.id, 'RESUME_COMPLETE') fail_msg = "Server is not in ACTIVE status." inst_status = self.compute_client.servers.get(instances[0].id).status self.verify_response_body_content(inst_status, 'ACTIVE', fail_msg, 6) # stack check fail_msg = "Stack check failed" self.verify(10, self.heat_client.actions.check, 7, fail_msg, "executing check stack action", stack.id) fail_msg = "Stack resource is not in CHECK_COMPLETE status." res_status = self.heat_client.resources.list( stack.id)[0].resource_status self.verify_response_body_content(res_status, 'CHECK_COMPLETE', fail_msg, 8) self.verify(60, self._wait_for_stack_status, 8, fail_msg, "stack status becoming 'CHECK_COMPLETE'", stack.id, 'CHECK_COMPLETE') # delete stack fail_msg = "Cannot delete stack." self.verify(20, self.heat_client.stacks.delete, 9, fail_msg, "deleting stack", stack.id) self.verify(100, self._wait_for_stack_deleted, 9, fail_msg, "deleting stack", stack.id)

commit_message:
Use alternative url string for Py3

By default Sqlalchemy uses MySQLdb aka python-mysqldb as MySQL driver.
This package doesn't provided for Py3. Instead of MySQLdb Py3 uses
PyMySQL. We should explicitly set MySQL Python driver in the connection
string when Py3 used.

Change-Id: I25ae303d0f825b9f9f8a7e8852353f1feb8af655
Closes-Bug: #1399138

commit_message:
Cleanup the update policy tests

- move test_autoscaling_update_policy into autoscaling/test_scaling_group
- add tests for update policy for heat scaling group
- remove test_scaling_group_create_error() as it is in the functional tests
  https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat_integrationtests/functional/test_autoscaling.py#L220
- rework the rolling update tests

part of blueprint decouple-nested
Change-Id: I176c767ba8f4a7c4f2b3184aec8b0daa72605233
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/48/158548/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.tests import generic_resource class ReplaceTest(common.HeatTestCase): scenarios = [( '1', dict(min_in_service=0, batch_size=1, updates=2), '2', dict(min_in_service=0, batch_size=2, updates=1), '3', dict(min_in_service=3, batch_size=1, updates=3), '4', dict(min_in_service=3, batch_size=2, updates=2))] def setUp(self): super(ReplaceTest, self).setUp() resource._register_class('ResourceWithPropsAndAttrs', generic_resource.ResourceWithPropsAndAttrs) t = template_format.parse(inline_templates.as_template) stack = utils.parse_stack(t, params=inline_templates.as_params) lc = self.create_launch_config(t, stack) lcid = lc.FnGetRefId() self.defn = rsrc_defn.ResourceDefinition( 'asg', 'OS::Heat::InstanceGroup', {'Size': 2, 'AvailabilityZones': ['zoneb'], 'LaunchConfigurationName': lcid}) self.group = instgrp.InstanceGroup('asg', self.defn, stack) self.group._lb_reload = mock.Mock() self.group.update_with_template = mock.Mock() self.group.check_update_complete = mock.Mock() self.group._nested = self.get_fake_nested_stack() def create_launch_config(self, t, stack): self.stub_ImageConstraint_validate() self.stub_FlavorConstraint_validate() self.stub_SnapshotConstraint_validate() self.m.ReplayAll() rsrc = stack['LaunchConfig'] self.assertIsNone(rsrc.validate()) scheduler.TaskRunner(rsrc.create)() self.assertEqual((rsrc.CREATE, rsrc.COMPLETE), rsrc.state) self.m.VerifyAll() return rsrc def get_fake_nested_stack(self): nested_t = ''' heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 description: AutoScaling Test resources: one: type: ResourceWithPropsAndAttrs properties: Foo: hello two: type: ResourceWithPropsAndAttrs properties: Foo: fee ''' return utils.parse_stack(template_format.parse(nested_t)) def test_rolling_updates(self): self.group._replace(self.min_in_service, self.batch_size, 0) self.assertEqual(self.updates, len(self.group.update_with_template.call_args_list)) self.assertEqual(self.updates + 1, len(self.group._lb_reload.call_args_list))

commit_message:
Consider dropping check on power state

This patch set stops to check the power state of the physical machine
before deploy.

(cherry picked from commit 49a85dba982a9acb5481038ce5ce3ec1c3e8b577)
Conflicts:
	ironic_discoverd/introspect.py
	ironic_discoverd/test/test_introspect.py

Change-Id: Icde18ec2fffd269605e78b1d5a9a0c080929a5b5
Closes-Bug: #1414986

commit_message:
Use revocation events for lightweight tokens

Allow lightweight tokens to take advantage of revocation events.

Change-Id: I850b94f4e324e6ec76e964eca8e2769144c39a98
Implements: bp klw-tokens
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/14/158414/19 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_revoke_unscoped_token(self): auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.user['id'], password=self.user['password']) resp = self.post('/auth/tokens', body=auth_data) unscoped_token = resp.headers.get('X-Subject-Token') self.assertTrue(unscoped_token.startswith('KLWT00')) headers = {'X-Subject-Token': unscoped_token} self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=200) self.delete('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=204) self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=404) def test_revoke_project_scoped_token(self): auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=self.user['id'], password=self.user['password'], project_id=self.project_id) resp = self.post('/auth/tokens', body=auth_data, expected_status=201) project_scoped_token = resp.headers.get('X-Subject-Token') self.assertTrue(project_scoped_token.startswith('KLWT00')) headers = {'X-Subject-Token': project_scoped_token} self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=200) self.delete('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=204) self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=404) def test_revoke_trust_scoped_token(self): # Create a trustee user trustee_user_ref = self.new_user_ref(domain_id=self.domain_id) trustee_user = self.identity_api.create_user(trustee_user_ref) trustee_user['password'] = trustee_user_ref['password'] ref = self.new_trust_ref( trustor_user_id=self.user_id, trustee_user_id=trustee_user['id'], project_id=self.project_id, impersonation=True, role_ids=[self.role_id]) # Create a trust r = self.post('/OS-TRUST/trusts', body={'trust': ref}) trust = self.assertValidTrustResponse(r) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=trustee_user['id'], password=trustee_user['password'], trust_id=trust['id']) resp = self.post('/auth/tokens', body=auth_data, expected_status=201) # Get a trust scoped token trust_scoped_token = resp.headers.get('X-Subject-Token') self.assertTrue(trust_scoped_token.startswith('KLWT01')) headers = {'X-Subject-Token': trust_scoped_token} # Validate a trust scoped token self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=200) self.delete('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=204) self.get('/auth/tokens', headers=headers, expected_status=404)

commit_message:
Properly implement authentication via keystonemiddleware

This requires introducing new option 'identity_uri'.

(cherry picked from commit e7e9e0b6f93453648f8d46d11ac2be277c2fb109)

Conflicts:
	README.rst
	ironic_discoverd/main.py
	ironic_discoverd/test/test_main.py
	ironic_discoverd/utils.py

Closes-Bug: #1427125
Change-Id: Ibed9cf163357c7b38f6e9a980900bcc1d9d12804

commit_message:
Passing privileged user to create nova assisted snapshots

This patch passes privileged user to create nova assisted
snapshots. We can pass privileged user credentials through
cinder.conf as below:
  os_privileged_user_name = <user>
  os_privileged_user_password = <password>
  os_privileged_user_tenant = <tenant>

Closes-Bug: 1308736
Change-Id: I004f3962f7c83113bed6bd9e3ccd002f017bd260

commit_message:
Log warning when --boolean-key and --key are used

These are not compatible, so log a warning when they're used together.

Change-Id: I8e72f90f9e789c413cba2e95543313c4a7bf95a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-apply-config refs/changes/49/155149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if opts.key and opts.boolean_key: logger.warning('--key is not compatible with --boolean-key.' ' --boolean-key ignored.')

added_lines: def test_dates_filtering(self): exporter = OswlStatsToCsv() # Creating oswls with not continuous created dates resource_type = consts.OSWL_RESOURCE_TYPES.vm oswl = OpenStackWorkloadStats( master_node_uid='x', external_id=1, cluster_id=1, created_date=datetime(2015, 2, 23).date(), updated_time=datetime.utcnow().time(), resource_type=resource_type, resource_checksum='', resource_data={'current': [{'id': 444, 'status': 'ACTIVE'}]} ) db.session.add(oswl) self.get_saved_inst_structs([oswl], creation_date_range=(0, 0)) db.session.commit() with app.test_request_context(): with mock.patch.object(flask.request, 'args', {'from_date': '2015-02-21', 'to_date': '2015-02-22'}): oswls = list(get_oswls(resource_type)) self.assertEqual(0, len(oswls)) result = exporter.export(resource_type, oswls, datetime(2015, 2, 22).date()) # Only column names in result self.assertEqual(1, len(list(result))) with mock.patch.object(flask.request, 'args', {'to_date': '2015-02-22'}): oswls = list(get_oswls(resource_type)) self.assertEqual(0, len(oswls)) result = exporter.export(resource_type, oswls, datetime(2015, 2, 22).date()) # Only column names in result self.assertEqual(1, len(list(result))) with mock.patch.object(flask.request, 'args', {'to_date': '2015-02-24'}): oswls = list(get_oswls(resource_type)) self.assertEqual(1, len(oswls)) result = exporter.export(resource_type, oswls, datetime(2015, 2, 24).date()) # Not only column names in result self.assertEqual(1 + 2, len(list(result)))

This change modifies the arguments that the LBaaS namespace
driver is passing to the L3 agent's linux driver's init_l3()
method, to match changes that are being made to the
init_l3() call signature as part of the Neutron
multiple-ipv6-prefixes blueprint.

As part of the changes for the multiple-ipv6-prefixes blueprint,
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149068)
the init_l3() method is being changed to accept a list
of dictionaries, each with 'cidr' (IP CIDR) and (optionally) a
matching 'gateway_ip', rather than a list of IP CIDRs and a
singular gateway IP address. This change was necessary because a
gateway port can now have multiple gateway IP addresses.

This change should not be merged until the change for
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149068 has been merged into
Neutron.

commit_message:
Modify LBaaS driver call to init_l3 for IPv6 multi-prefix

This change modifies the arguments that the LBaaS namespace
driver is passing to the L3 agent's linux driver's init_l3()
method, to match changes that are being made to the
init_l3() call signature as part of the Neutron
multiple-ipv6-prefixes blueprint.

As part of the changes for the multiple-ipv6-prefixes blueprint,
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149068)
the init_l3() method is being changed to accept a list
of dictionaries, each with 'cidr' (IP CIDR) and (optionally) a
matching 'gateway_ip', rather than a list of IP CIDRs and a
singular gateway IP address. This change was necessary because a
gateway port can now have multiple gateway IP addresses.

This change should not be merged until the change for
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/149068 has been merged into
Neutron.

Change-Id: I5f9c69bf194401d7ec62803405a375cd521a6ccc
Depends-On: I150da5938e79eeef0c947ddb1a4282e37d0515ee
Partially-implements: blueprint multiple-ipv6-prefixes

commit_message:
Listener, Pool, Member, and HealthMonitor Managers

Implemented the Listener, Pool, Member, and HealthMonitor managers
to the agent driver.  Also implemented the create, update and
delete methods for each of those entities in the Agent API which
is responsible for sending the data to the queue.

Depends-On: Ic9179ef0a95b91d1b7662537fffeb0a949efc925
Partially-implements: blueprint lbaas-refactor-haproxy-namespace-driver-to-new-driver-interface
Co-Authored-By: Brandon Logan <brandon.logan@rackspace.com>

Change-Id: Ifdba5c931eb1b0f23e6388fcc535e37e8f297b07

commit_message:
Finish Agent Scheduler and LB Agent Driver Piece

Implements the agent scheduler to choose which agent will host
the loadbalancer.  Only a random scheduling algorithm implemented.

Exposed two API calls that allows an admin user to get a list of
loadbalancers hosted by an agent and get the agent that is hosting
a particular loadbalancer.

Implemented the loadbalancer driver classes and methods for the agent
driver.  These will call the agent scheduler to host the load balancer
and then send the data to a queue.

Depends-On: Ic9179ef0a95b91d1b7662537fffeb0a949efc925
Partially-implements: blueprint lbaas-refactor-haproxy-namespace-driver-to-new-driver-interface
Co-Authored-By: Brandon Logan <brandon.logan@rackspace.com>

Change-Id: Ic4a83ef255aed0474eebb73f28d67e09f35666b7

commit_message:
Add cascade deletion for tables relating to nodes

Batch deletion of nodes was impossible without setting ON DELETE CASCADE for
foreignt key constraint for tables
  node_roles,
  pending_node_roles,
  node_attributes

Change-Id: Iee147ec13f2f533492099639112ac983c04addaa
Closes-Bug: #1423872
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/97/158297/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Avoid ObjectDeletedError while accessing deleted binding

In some cases access to db object's attribute triggers its refresh.
When the object has been already removed from the database, it could
lead to ObjectDeletedError being thrown.
Unit test was added to cover code path where the issue occurs
however issue doesn't seem to be reproducible with sqlite.

Change-Id: I0d6f9a91572c89cf7da1b66b880aeaa6b4b1987e
Closes-Bug: #1424593

commit_message:
Tweak functor used to find flatteners/storage routines

Make both of these finding functions use similar routines
that the utility module now provides since the logic that
both use can be shared.

Change-Id: Ib941b99945d42f5c0d791e9b2a0696d0e62a2388
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/16/160616/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def match_type_handler(item, type_handlers): """Matches a given items type using the given match types + handlers. Returns the handler if a type match occurs, otherwise none. """ for (match_types, handler_func) in type_handlers: if isinstance(item, match_types): return handler_func else: return None

subject: ovs_neutron_agent should exit gracefully
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-05 06:03:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/58830961c20523753887e982e5955ce612f68277', 'message': "ovs_dead, ovs-agent booting up code should exit graceful

Currently, ovs-agent doesn't check ovs_dead during its boot up process.
That leads to an ungraceful exit.

In this patch set we are displaying the status of ovs and terminating
the ovs agent if ovs is not running.

Closes-Bug: #1351135

commit_message:
ovs_neutron_agent should exit gracefully

In this patch set if any error occurs during agent initialization
phase, then it terminates ovs neutron agent gracefully.

Closes-Bug: #1351135

Co-Authored-By:Aman Kumar <amank@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By:Neethi Shasidhar <neethi209@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I14d091c73c8f8f4dfe70e7f9a7f7683b5fb0fd7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/38/153138/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Checks for ovs status during neutron agent boot up process match_stat = "not running" status, output = commands.getstatusoutput(cfg.CONF.OVS.ovs_status_path) check_ovs_status = output.find(match_stat) if check_ovs_status > 1: sys.exit(output)

commit_message:
Add specific scoping documentation

Adds information into the arguments and result
docs about how scoping lookup works and what it
implies.

Change-Id: I810874dce042ec43fe9e704d6689215e19d67c9c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/57/158957/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Scoping ======= During creation of flows it is also important to understand the lookup strategy (also typically known as `scope`_) that the engine you are using will internally used. For example when task ``A`` provides result 'a' and a task ``B`` after ``A`` provides a different named result 'a' and a task ``C`` after ``A`` and after ``B`` requires 'a' to run, which one will= be selected? In the case of the default engine (see :doc:`engines <engines>` for an overview of what engines are) the lookup strategy is documented in the following class: .. autoclass:: taskflow.engines.action_engine.scopes.ScopeWalker :special-members: __iter__ Selection ordering ------------------ When a engine is executed it internally interacts with the :py:class:`~taskflow.storage.Storage` class and that class interacts with the a :py:class:`~taskflow.engines.action_engine.scopes.ScopeWalker` instance and the :py:class:`~taskflow.storage.Storage` class uses the following lookup order to find (or fail) a valid atoms argument: #. Injected atom specific arguments. #. Transient injected arguments. #. Non-transient injected arguments. #. First scope visited group that produces the named result, note that if multiple providers are found the first (the scope iterator ordering defines what first means) that produced that result and can be extracted without raising an error is selected. #. Fail with :py:class:`~taskflow.exceptions.NotFound` if unresolved at this point. .. note:: To examine this this information when debugging it is recommended to enable the ``BLATHER`` logging level (level 5). At this level the storage and scope code/layers will log what is being searched for and what is being found. .. _scope: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scope_%28computer_science%29

commit_message:
Adding required jobs for supported datastores

Reasons:
 - it is required to have check jobs for all supported
   datastores to avoid bug omissions.

Changes:
 - adding per-datastore check job 'files' directive to enable advanced
   job execution procedure.

Change-Id: Iaaec153f2530f6671b046ea6a26307068c296b43

subject: Use Nova attachment API for attaching volume during instance scheduling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-22 16:14:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/3c4e0f658fbd15200b081ef42edcc4be6266521d', 'message': "Use Nova attachment API for attaching volume during instance scheduling

Reasons:
 - for VMWare hypervisor nova raises exception due to invalid block device mapping
   (possible there are couple hypervisors that are also might be affected);
 - using best practices for managing volumes in OpenStack (see Heat's VolumeAttached
   resources that uses direct attach procedure);

Changes:
 - new configuration option - use_volume_attachment (type: boolean, default: True).
   This option defines how would volume be attached to an instance.
   If 'True', taskamanger will use Nova API to attach volume,
   if 'False', Taskmanager will use block device mapping instead.
 - new private function proposed: _attach_volume. It asks Nova to attach volume
   onto ACTIVE server and polls until volume would reach 'in-use' state.

Note: for safe volume mounting it is required to wait until
      server would reach ACTIVE state.

DocImpact: new configuration option was added.

Change-Id: Iffa59bbec2c031aced67b614298c804003a9e873
Closes-Bug: #1395115

commit_message:
Use Nova attachment API for attaching volume during instance scheduling

Reasons:
 - for VMWare hypervisor nova raises exception due to invalid block device mapping
   (possible there are couple hypervisors that are also might be affected);
 - using best practices for managing volumes in OpenStack (see Heat's VolumeAttached
   resources that uses direct attach procedure);

Changes:
 - new configuration option - use_volume_attachment (type: boolean, default: True).
   This option defines how would volume be attached to an instance.
   If 'True', taskamanger will use Nova API to attach volume,
   if 'False', Taskmanager will use block device mapping instead.
 - new private function proposed: _attach_volume. It asks Nova to attach volume
   onto ACTIVE server and polls until volume would reach 'in-use' state.

Note: for safe volume mounting it is required to wait until
      server would reach ACTIVE state.

DocImpact: new configuration option was added.

Change-Id: Iffa59bbec2c031aced67b614298c804003a9e873
Closes-Bug: #1395115

commit_message:
Implement MongoDB clustering integration tests

Changes:
 - added fake-mode testing
 - added integration tests

Note:
 - testing group is shared
 - example generator updated examples

HOWTO. Using trove-integration run next commands:
 1. redstack install
 2. redstack kick-start mongodb
 3. redstacl int-tests --group=mongodb_clustering

Change-Id: I164eac10160cae6fb4c46d998b7bf1ffb15417ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/20/147920/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # MongoDB mongodb_datastore_id = utils.generate_uuid() mongodb_datastore_version_id = utils.generate_uuid() models.DBDatastore.create(id=mongodb_datastore_id, name="mongodb", default_version_id= mongodb_datastore_version_id) models.DBDatastoreVersion.create( id=mongodb_datastore_version_id, datastore_id=mongodb_datastore_id, name="2.6.1", manager="mongodb", packages='test_packages', image_id=utils.generate_uuid(), active=1 ) # 'clustering' runs both clusterin groups: cassandra and mongodb

Given patchset provides:
 - cluster provisioning
   - cluster modifications:
   - adding seed node to existing cluster;
   - adding data node to existing cluster.

TODO:
 - implement recoverers for those actions that are modifying cluster state, such as:
 - adding seed node (this action involves data node state modifications);
 - implement workflow that allows to safe delete procedure
   for any node(independently from their type) from cluster;
 - implement cluster int-tests.

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

        setUp                                                       OK  0.18

Slowest 5 tests took 2602.33 secs:
    2598.24    proboscis.case.MethodTest (test_wait_until_cluster_is_active)
    1.03       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_glance_registry)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_glance_api)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_trove_api)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_compute)

As it can be seen, cluster provisioning test takes at very least 43 minutes.
So, when this test group would be proposed as regular job
to OpenStack Infra gating, it does make sense to set job timeout for 90 minutes.

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

commit_message:
Implement TM and Guest strategies for Cassandra datastore

Given patchset provides:
- cluster provisioning
- cluster modifications:
  - adding seed node to existing cluster;
  - adding data node to existing cluster.

TODO:
- implement recoverers for those actions that are modifying cluster state, such as:
- adding seed node (this action involves data node state modifications);
- implement workflow that allows to safe delete procedure
  for any node(independently from their type) from cluster;

Example generator(with --fix-examples)  added new updates to existing files.

Integration testing details:

CreateCassandraCluster
        setUp                                                       OK  0.18
        test_cassandra_datastore_and_its_version_for_existance      OK  0.09
        test_create_cluster_with_different_flavors                  OK  0.07
        test_create_cluster_with_different_volumes                  OK  0.20
        test_create_cluster_without_seed_nodes                      OK  0.38
        test_create_cluster_successfuly                             OK  0.52
        test_wait_until_cluster_is_active                         OK 2598.24
        test_add_data_node_to_building_cluster            SKIP: To be added.
        test_add_seed_node_to_building_cluster            SKIP: To be added.
        test_cluster_delete                                         OK 40.21

OK (SKIP=2)
Slowest 5 tests took 2602.33 secs:
    2598.24    proboscis.case.MethodTest (test_wait_until_cluster_is_active)
    40.21      proboscis.case.MethodTest (test_cluster_delete)
    1.03       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_glance_registry)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_glance_api)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_trove_api)
    1.02       proboscis.case.FunctionTest (start_compute)

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

Change-Id: I6cbfb57c0077fcd60895131113371fb3c6eb1eb5

added_lines: from trove.common.strategies.cassandra import ( taskmanager as taskmanager_strategy)from trove.taskmanager import api as task_api from trove.tests.fakes import guestagentfrom trove.tests.unittests.util import util def _get_cluster_instances(self, cluster): cluster_instances = [ db_info for db_info in instance_models.DBInstance.find_all( cluster_id=cluster.id) ] return cluster_instances def _get_cluster_instance_service_statuses(self, cluster): instances = self._get_cluster_instances(cluster) cluster_instance_service_statuses = [] for cluster_instance in instances: cluster_instance_service_statuses.append( instance_models.InstanceServiceStatus.get_by( instance_id=cluster_instance.id) ) return cluster_instance_service_statuses def _set_cluster_instance_statuses_to_active(self, cluster, statuses=[]): statuses = (self._get_cluster_instance_service_statuses(cluster) if not statuses else statuses) for status in statuses: status.set_status(instance.ServiceStatuses.RUNNING) status.save() def _get_cluster(self, cluster_id): cluster = api.CassandraCluster.load( self.context, cluster_id) return cluster def _setup_cluster(self): instances = self.valid_instance cluster = api.CassandraCluster.create( self.context, self.cluster_name, self.datastore, self.version, instances) cluster_instances = self._get_cluster_instances( cluster) cluster_instance_service_statuses = ( self._get_cluster_instance_service_statuses( cluster) ) return ( cluster, cluster_instances, cluster_instance_service_statuses ) class fake_server(object): def __init__(self): self.status = "ACTIVE" self.addresses = {"addr": "127.0.0.1"} def setup_cluster(self): task_api.load = mock.MagicMock() instance_models.load_server = mock.MagicMock( return_value=None ) instance_models.Instance.get_visible_ip_addresses = ( mock.MagicMock(return_value=["127.0.0.1"])) cluster, instances, statuses = self._setup_cluster() self.assertIsNotNone(cluster) self.assertIsNotNone(instances) self.assertIsNotNone(statuses) strategy = ( taskmanager_strategy. CassandraClusterTasks( self.context, cluster.db_info)) return strategy, cluster, instances, statuses def _raise(self, exception_class): def do_raise(*args, **kwargs): raise exception_class() return do_raise def _extend_cluster_with_node(self, action, node_type, wrapper=None, exception_to_raise=None, exception_to_handle=None): (strategy, cluster, instances, statuses) = self.setup_cluster() self._set_cluster_instance_statuses_to_active( cluster, statuses=statuses) with mock.patch.object(instance_models, 'load_server', return_value=self.fake_server()): with mock.patch.object( taskmanager_strategy.CassandraClusteringWorkflow, 'get_ip', return_value="1.1.1.1"): with mock.patch.object( taskmanager_strategy.CassandraClusterTasks, 'get_guest', return_value=guestagent.FakeGuest( instances[0].id)): strategy.create_cluster( self.context, cluster.id) self.controller.action( self.fake_request(self.context), {action: {}}, self.context.tenant, cluster.id) self._add_node_action(cluster, strategy, node_type, wrapper=wrapper, exception_to_raise= exception_to_raise, exception_to_handle= exception_to_handle) def wrapper(self, action_method, context, cluster_id, node_id, exception_to_handle=None, exception_to_raise=None): def wrap(): if exception_to_handle: with mock.patch.object( taskmanager_strategy.CassandraClusteringWorkflow, "_check_cluster_nodes_are_active", side_effect=self._raise(exception_to_raise)): self.assertRaises(exception_to_handle, action_method, context, cluster_id, node_id) else: action_method(context, cluster_id, node_id) return wrap def _add_node_action(self, cluster, strategy, node_type, wrapper=None, exception_to_raise=None, exception_to_handle=None): cluster_instances = ( instance_models.Instances.load_all_by_cluster_id( self.context, cluster.id, load_servers=False)) new_node = [node for node in cluster_instances if node.type == node_type and "node-4" in node.name].pop() self._set_cluster_instance_statuses_to_active(cluster) action = getattr(strategy, "add_%s_to_cluster" % node_type) if wrapper and callable(wrapper): examine = wrapper(action, self.context, cluster.id, new_node.id, exception_to_raise= exception_to_raise, exception_to_handle= exception_to_handle) examine() else: action(self.context, cluster.id, new_node.id)

commit_message:
Implement API strategy for Cassandra clustering

Given patchset implements next cases for Cassandra datastore:
1. Cluster provisioning.
2. Cluster modification through next actions:
  2.1 add_seed_node
  2.2 add_data_node

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

Change-Id: Ib53bd4c91c4f1b5461f1779fc2765ade6ad7d07c

commit_message:
Adding required configuration for clustering int-tests

Changes:
 - cluster size = 1
   initial_cluster_data_to_seed_nodes_ratio = 0
   token_modification_timeout = 10000
   to test small Cassandra cluster

 - num_query_routers_per_cluster = 1,
   num_config_servers_per_cluster = 1
   smallfiles = True
   for MongoDB sharded cluster for same reasons as above.

 - usage_timeout = 10000
 - agent_call_high_timeout = 300

Partially implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

Change-Id: I28629ae218395c565ed643bd9c702453230ee22f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/98/146098/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function setup_clustering_configuration() { exclaim "Setting Trove to run clustering integration tests for supported datastores." # Cassandra clustering configuration iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove.conf cassandra cluster_size 1 iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove.conf cassandra initial_cluster_data_to_seed_nodes_ratio 0 # MongoDB clustering configuration iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove.conf mongodb num_config_servers_per_cluster 1 iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove.conf mongodb num_query_routers_per_cluster 1 # Trove common configuration iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove-taskmanager.conf DEFAULT usage_timeout 1000 iniset $TROVE_CONF_DIR/trove-taskmanager.conf DEFAULT agent_call_high_timeout 300 } setup_clustering_configuration

commit_message:
Apply cluster action modifications to client library

Reasons:
 - Cassandra clustering implementation requires to submit
   'type' instance attribute as part of initial cluster
   provisioning request;
 - cluster actions execution requires client API and
    shell representation.

Changes:
 - adding client API that reflect cluster action execution
   against cluster.

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

Change-Id: I443f4283beca452ad17e4907399a1d2f45b5f1d4
