commit_message:
Spec for instance metadata

APIImpact New API for instance metadata functionality

This patch contains two different specs:

	- initial spec for instance-metadata API
          proposed by imsplitbit

	- alternative spec for generic metadata API
          proposed by denis_makogon

Change-Id: Ifacb978d8c5380ea8d32374c7f507bfa6298b5ee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/77/136577/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None ===================== Instance metadata API ===================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/trove-metadata Problem description =================== Description ----------- Instance metadata is a feature that has been requested frequently by our users. They need a way to store critical information for their instances and have that be associated with the instance so that it is displayed whenever that instance is listed via the API. This also becomes very usable from a testing perspective when doing integration/ci. We can utilize the metadata to store things like what process created the instance, what the instance is being used for, etc... The design for this feature is modeled heavily on the Nova metadata API with a few tweaks in how it works internally. With the likelihood of an OpenStack official metadata service on the horizon I felt like we needed to keep the entry point of integration very small so that when that service becomes available there will be little code in the instance model to change to make that integration happen. To achieve this I made the model work using the dictionary interface and kept all the heavy lifting and fetching/saving operations are internal to the model and happen automatically when keys are modified. All keys *must* be strings. Acceptable value types are:: Lists Dictionaries Strings Integers Floats Goals ----- Give trove users the ability to store key/value pairs that have significance to them but is not essential to trove's functionality Create a user accessible rest API to manage instance metadata Mimic the design/interface used by Nova for metadata Implement the model so that it acts like a dictionary to make hooking in metadata into the instance very easy and small Proposed change =============== Configuration ------------- No configuration changes are expected. Database -------- Table name: instance_metadata Table columns:: Name | Type | NULLABLE -------------------------------------- id | String(36) | instance_id | String(36) | True key | String(255)| value | Text | created | DateTime | updated | DateTime | deleted | Boolean | deleted_at | DateTime | Constraints:: There is a unique constraint on the fields instance_id and key together to prevent duplicate keys per instance. There is code in the model and controller to prevent this also but the unique constraint is there as an added layer of security. Public API ---------- The following section describes the API interface both what needs to be sent to the api and what the responses look like:: Create API Call:: API Path and Method: POST /instances/{id}/metadata/{key} Body:: { "metadata": { "value": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5]}} } } API Response:: Response Codes:: Positive: 200 Negative: 400 Response Body:: { "metadata": { "newKey": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5]}} } } Update API Call:: API Path and Method:: PUT /instances/{id}/metadata/{key} Body:: { "metadata": { "key": "newKey2", "value": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5]}} } } API Response:: Response Codes Positive: 200 Negative: 404 Response Body:: None Replace API Call:: API Path and Method: PATCH /instances/{id}/metadata/{key} Body:: { "metadata": { "value": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5], "key2": "the value of this key is a string"}} } } API Response:: Response Codes:: Positive: 200 Negative: 404 Response Body:: None Delete API Call:: API Path and Method: DELETE /instances/{id}/metadata/{key} Body:: None API Response:: Response Codes:: Positive 200 Negative 404 Response Body:: None Show API Call:: API Path and Method: GET /instances/{id}/metadata/{key} Body:: None API Response:: Response Codes:: Positive 200 Negative 404 Response Body:: { "metadata": { "newKey": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5]}} } } List API Call:: API Path and Method: GET /instances/{id}/metadata Body:: None API Response:: Response Codes:: Positive: 200 No negative code because this returns an empty dictionary when no metadata exists for the instance Response Body:: { "metadata": { "myKey": {"one": {"two": [3, 4, 5]}}, "keyTwo": "I wanted to store this sentence for this key" } } Integration with Instance ------------------------- First pass I will not allow metadata to be passed in on instance create however this should be added soon after. You will however be able to see metadata in the instance object when you do a SHOW on the instance. Also when deleting an instance all metadata is deleted to keep things neat and tidy. Internal API ------------ No changes are required. Guest Agent ----------- No changes are required. Alternatives ------------ No alternatives. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee:: Launchpad:: dmakogon IRC:: denis_makogon Milestones ---------- Kilo-[1,2] Work Items ---------- Implementation is ready to be reviewed, [1]. Dependencies ============ No dependencies. Testing ======= Unit, fake/real integration tests would be proposed. Documentation Impact ==================== New API samples are should be proposed. References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/82123 [2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Trove-Instance-Metadata

commit_message:
Spec for Cassandra datastore full backup/restore

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-backup-restore

Change-Id: I811879032c754ccc49cf5cf21417bd830a9758c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/72/136572/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None ===================================== Support Cassandra full backup/restore ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/cassandra-backup-restore Problem description =================== Cassandra is one of supported datastores, but its driver for guestagent does only basic things:: provisioning resizing (volume/flavor) There's need to perform backups through Trove directly because users are not allowed to access instance directly, so there's no way for users to manage their data in regular manner. This blueprint aims to cover given functionality gap for Cassandra guestagent driver. Proposed change =============== For backup procedure Trove-guestagent will use native tool that comes out of box with Cassandra:: nodetool [1] It allows to take a snapshot for keyspace or columnfamily or of all datastore. Here's an example how nodetools does snapshoting - [2]. How snapshot looks like? ------------------------ Suppose we have datastore, pre-filled with some keyspaces. File system data structure of the Cassandra's datastore with snapshot looks like:: /var/lib/cassandra/data/{keyspace_name}/{SSTable_name-UUID}/snapshot/{snapshot_name} How to create a backup? ----------------------- Here you can see a list of required operations that are needed to package backup:: flush in-memory data clear previous snapshots look-up over datastore for snapshot directories find all snaptshots of all, including system, keyspaces collect all snaptshots package snapshots Here you can see a list of detailed commands(with respect to packaging procedure) to perform backup of an Cassandra's datastore:: Pre-backup(pre-snapshot and snapshot steps):: # nodetool flush # nodetool clearsnapshot %(backup_name)s 2>&1>/dev/null # nodetool snapshot -t %(backup_name)s 1>/dev/null Backup(packaging step):: # "sudo tar cpPf - $(sudo find %(datadir)s -type d -name %(backup_name)s) Post-backup:: # nodetool clearsnapshot -t %(backup_name)s 2>&1>/dev/null Once we have packaged backup we can push it into remote Storage, for example Swift container. How to restore an instance from backup? --------------------------------------- Here you can see a list of operations required to restore an instance from backup:: unpackage a backup delete package delete system keyspace iterate over all keyspaces in given backup iterate over all directories in each keyspaces directory find all *.db files and moves them from [1] to [2] [1] /tmp/var/${data_dir}/${keyspace}/${directories}/snapshots/{snapshot_name} [2] /tmp/var/${data_dir}/${keyspace}/${directories}/ find and delete snapshot directories to be able to copy [1] directory to [2] [1] /tmp/var/${data_dir} [2] /var/${data_dir} copy data to destination directory from [1] tp [2] [1] /tmp/var/${data_dir} [2] /var/${data_dir} remove unpacked backup You may have a question about removing system keyspace. Per a conversation with the nice folks in #cassandra on irc (see log at [3]), we should NOT restore system keyspaces. Why not include the system keyspaces in the backup, but on restore, ignore/don't-use them. the reasoning here is that it's possibly useful if something goes really awry, and you need *some* sort of artifact to tell you what the system used to look like. Here you can see a list of detailed commands(with respect to restoring procedure):: # sudo tar xfzp %(filename)s -C /tmp 2>&1>/dev/null # sudo rm -f %(filename)s # rm -fr /tmp/var/lib/cassandra/data/system # data_dir="/tmp/var/lib/cassandra/data" && for keyspace in `sudo ls -1 ${data_dir}`; do for directories in `sudo ls -1 ${data_dir}/${keyspace}`; do i=`sudo find ${data_dir}/${keyspace}/${directories} -name *.db`; sudo mv -f $i ${data_dir}/${keyspace}/${directories}/ 2>/dev/null; done ; done; # sudo rm -rf $(sudo find /tmp/var/lib/cassandra/data/ -type d -name snapshots) # sudo cp -p -R /tmp/var/lib/cassandra/data/ %(datadir)s # sudo rm -fr /tmp/var Configuration ------------- Changing defaults for:: backup_namespace - NodetoolSnapshot Adding new configurations:: Name: restore_namespace Type: String Default: trove.guestagent.strategies.backup.cassandra.NodetoolSnapshot Name: backup_strategy Type: String Default: trove.guestagent.strategies.restore.cassandra.NodetoolSnapshot Database -------- No changes are required. Public API ---------- No changes are required. Internal API ------------ No changes are required. Guest Agent ----------- Adding new file(files are including implementation of backup/restore strategies):: guestagent/strategies/backup/cassandra.py guestagent/strategies/restore/cassandra.py Updating:: guestagent/datastore/cassandra/manager.py Given changes are backward compatible. Alternatives ------------ No alternatives. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee:: Launchpad:: dmakogon IRC:: denis_makogon Milestones ---------- Kilo-2 Work Items ---------- Implementation is ready to be reviewed, [4]. Dependencies ============ No dependencies. Testing ======= Unit tests are going to be proposed. Integration tests are already implemented. Documentation Impact ==================== DocImpact will take its place due to Configuration section References ========== [1] http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/tools/toolsNodetool_r.html [2] http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/tools/toolsSnapShot.html [3] https://gist.github.com/amcrn/dc7d013cb5321871ba15 [4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/77551/

commit_message:
Fix Redis Ubuntu elements for Ubuntu Trusty Tahr

Reasons:
 - image elements are trying to add a duplicate
   of Ubuntu Tahr source repository;
 - due to specific configuration of repository that comes
   from image element Redis installation is failing
   due to unmet dependencies

Changes:
 - adding proper fix to 10-redis element
 - fixing redstack script with appropriate Redis version

Change-Id: Iddfa2d90a05498e59642ff2f856f19551e9883e7
Closes-Bug: #1391590
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/71/133771/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: apt-get install -y redis-server=2:2.8.4-2
deleted_lines: echo "deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu trusty main universe" >> /etc/apt/sources.list.d/trusty.sources.list # The following preferences say: # never install trusty packages... # ...except for redis-server and redis-tools (501 is higher than default priority) cat << EOF >> /etc/apt/preferences.d/redis-trusty Package: * Pin: release n=trusty Pin-Priority: -10 Package: redis-server redis-tools Pin: release n=trusty Pin-Priority: 501 EOF apt-get update apt-get install -y redis-server

commit_message:
Fix PostgreSQL elements to work properly on Ubuntu Trusty Tahr

Reasons:
 - Ubuntu Trusty Tahr doesn't have postgresql-9.1 package,
   recent version for Trusty - 9.3.

Changes:
 - fixing ubuntu image elements for PostgreSQL
 - fixing PostgreSQL version in redstack script

Change-Id: I667990a668bb23c422a7bb8ed914cce02fb5324a
Closes-Bug: #1391585

deleted_lines: PACKAGES=${PACKAGES:-"postgresql-9.1"}

commit_message:
Added Cassandra cluster spec

Partially Implements: blueprint cassandra-cluster

Change-Id: I4e78af7c6a8f5f61bf38029b30084ea3c42193e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/36/122736/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. ======================================== Implement cassandra cluster provisioning ======================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/cassandra-cluster Since Trove aims to become production-grade DBaaS its abilities should meet market needs. Among all overcloud applications (such as Click-a-Tell, Reddit), that are using OpenStack is service layer, there are lots of applications that were designed to work with NoSQL, in this case - with Cassandra, databases. The choise of Cassandra was made from next considerations:: - flat deployement schema - simple scale up/down procedure - easy maintenance and backuping Useful links:: http://cassandra.apache.org/ http://planetcassandra.org/blog/introduction-to-cassandra-clusters/ http://pulasthisupun.blogspot.com/2013/12/setting-up-local-3-node-cassandra.html http://www.slideshare.net/valstadsve/cassandra-in-production http://www.datastax.com/documentation/datastax_enterprise/4.5/datastax_enterprise/deploy/deployConfigRep.html http://www.datastax.com/documentation/datastax_enterprise/4.5/datastax_enterprise/deploy/deployMultiDC.html http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/architecture/architecturePlanningAbout_c.html http://planetcassandra.org/blog/reddit-upvotes-apache-cassandras-horizontal-scaling-managing-17000000-votes-daily/ http://jonathanhui.com/cassandra-data-maintenance-backup-and-system-recovery Problem description =================== There are alot overcloud projects that are requesting for NoSQL backend. This is perfect place to propose Trove as deployment tool, but before that we need to cover customer use cases with NoSQL deployment. From customer and maintainer point of view - Cassandra is the easiest to deploy-and-maintain datastore in the NoSQL eco-system. For now Trove supports only single instance provisioning of Cassandra datastore - this is a big problem for production deployments. In favor of stability, data distribution and protection Trove must support clustering for Cassandra datastore to meet market needs. Also, there are several projects, from OpenStack ecosystem, such as Ceilometer and MagnetoDB that may work with Cassandra as well. Useful links:: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/cassandra-driver https://github.com/stackforge/magnetodb/tree/master/magnetodb/storage/driver/cassandra https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/support-magnetodb Proposed change =============== Since Trove provides well-designed framework for implementing clustering for different datastores certain efforts needs to be applied to accomplish clustering procedure for Cassandra datastore. In the list below you can see next development plan:: - API strategy (needs for handling API requests, see base API strategy class https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/trove/common/strategies/base.py ). Includes specific to Cassandra datastore regular and MGMT views. - Taskmanager strategy (needs to handle cluster provisioning). This layer speaks to OpenStack projects to obtain needed resources, such as compute instances, volumes. This strategy will include next steps:: - cluster instance provisioning - post-provisioning configuration (gathering required info, such as instance IPs, rendering configuration template with collected data, applying rendered template to each of instances) - cluster deployment verification - Guestagent strategy (needs to handle RPC API calls from Taskmanager). Includes specific PRC API calls implementation. Cluster quota usage ------------------- Cassandra cluster doesn't require additonal servers to keep cluster alive (see mongod sharding). Minimum cluster size - 3 instances. Cassandra snitching ------------------- For production usage DataStax suggests to use Dynamic Snitch. From DataStax docs:: The dynamic snitch is enabled by default and is recommended for use in most deployments. Useful links:: http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/architecture/architectureSnitchDynamic_c.html http://www.datastax.com/dev/blog/dynamic-snitching-in-cassandra-past-present-and-future http://www.datastax.com/documentation/cassandra/2.0/cassandra/configuration/configCassandra_yaml_r.html?scroll=reference_ds_qfg_n1r_1k__dynamic_snitch_badness_threshold Configuration ------------- To enable clustering for Cassandra datastore next options needs to be added:: cluster_support - describes the availability of clustering feature. Type: Boolean api_strategy - fully qualified class name of aAPI strategy implementation. Type: String taskmanager_strategy - fully qualified class name of a Taskmanager implementation. Type: String guestagent_strategy - fully qualified class name of a Guestagent implementation. Type: String Database -------- None Public API ---------- -------------- Create Cluster -------------- HTTP Method. Route: POST /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters Request:: { "cluster": { "name": "test_cluster", "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "instances": [ { "flavorRef": "2", "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "flavorRef": "2", "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "flavorRef": "2", "volume": { "size": 100 } } ] } } Response:: { "cluster": { "id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "task": { "id": 2, "name": "BUILDING", "description": "Building the initial cluster." }, "name": "test_cluster", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "instances": [ { "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "965ef811-7c1d-47fc-89f2-a89dfdd23ef2", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } } ] } } Notes:: - Minimum flavor for cluster node should contain at least 4Gb RAM - Creates a cluster, with a 3 nodes, each cluster memer with the same flavor (memory + vcpu) and volume-size. - The name of each instance will be automatically generated; it will be the <cluster_name>-node-<instance_num> In this example, the instance names will be "test_cluster-node-1", "test_cluster-node-2", and "test_cluster-node-3". - Flavor and volume-size must be identical for all instances in cluster for predictable perfomance. - The number of instances in a cluster must be at least 3. ------------ Show Cluster ------------ Request:: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters/<cluster_id> Response:: { "cluster": { "id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "task": { "id": 1, "name": "NONE", "description": "No tasks for the cluster." }, "name": "test_cluster", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.1", "10.0.0.2", "10.0.0.3",], "instances": [ { "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "965ef811-7c1d-47fc-89f2-a89dfdd23ef2", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } } ] } } Notes:: - The ip/hostname returned is the list of each cluster instance. ------------- Show Instance ------------- Request:: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters/<cluster_id>/instances/<instance_id> Response:: { "instance": { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "cluster_id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "shard_id": "5415b62f-f301-4e84-ba90-8ab0734d15a7", "name": "test_cluster-node-1", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}], }, "volume": { "size": 100, "used": 0.42 } } } or alternatively, the existing route can be used: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/instances/<instance_id> Response:: { "instance": { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "cluster_id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "shard_id": "5415b62f-f301-4e84-ba90-8ab0734d15a7", "name": "test_cluster-node-1", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.1"], "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}], }, "volume": { "size": 100, "used": 0.42 }, } } Explanation GET /instance/<id> must function as before to avoid introducing a breaking change Notes:: - cluster_id must be added to GET /instance/<id>, otherwise users will not be able to discover the cluster-id for an instance that is discovered via GET /instances?include_clustered=true - ip/hostname is returned in GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters/<cluster-id>/instances/<instance-id> because each node is accessible for CRUD operations. ------------- List Clusters ------------- Request:: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters Response:: { "clusters": [ { "id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "task": { "id": 1, "name": "NONE", "description": "No tasks for the cluster." }, "name": "test_cluster", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "instances": [ { "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "965ef811-7c1d-47fc-89f2-a89dfdd23ef2", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } } ] }, ... ] } -------------- List Instances -------------- HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/instances Request:: { } Response:: { "instances": [ ], } Explanation GET /instances prior to clustering returned only standalone instances, and to honor that contract, we will filter out instances that belong to a cluster. Request:: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/instances?include_clustered=false Response:: { "instances": [ ], } Request:: HTTP Method. Route: GET /v1.0/<tenant_id>/instances?include_clustered=true Response:: { "instances": [ { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "cluster_id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "name": "test_cluster-node-1", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.1"], "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}], }, "volume": { "size": 100, "used": 0.17 } }, { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "cluster_id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "shard_id": "5415b62f-f301-4e84-ba90-8ab0734d15a7", "name": "test_cluster-node-2", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.2"], "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}], }, "volume": { "size": 100, "used": 0.17 } }, { "status": "ACTIVE", "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "cluster_id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "shard_id": "5415b62f-f301-4e84-ba90-8ab0734d15a7", "name": "test_cluster-node-3", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.3"], "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}], }, "volume": { "size": 100, "used": 0.17 } } ] } HTTP Method. Route: POST /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters/<cluster_id> Request:: { "add_shard": {} } Note:: - The additional "shard" represents a single instance extension to cluster that would be equal to all existing nodes in cluster - For the IP/hostname would be returned a list of previously provisioned cluster instances - With "Show Instance", "List Instances", and "List Clusters" impacted as one would expect A "Show Cluster" operation for this cluster would now result in:: { "cluster": { "id": "dfbbd9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-f78643e17998", "task": { "id": 4, "name": "ADDING_SHARD", "description": "Adding a shard to the cluster." }, "name": "products", "created": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "updated": "2014-04-25T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "cassandra", "version": "2.10" }, "ip": ["10.0.0.1", "10.0.0.2", "10.0.0.3"], "instances": [ { "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "965ef811-7c1d-47fc-89f2-a89dfdd23ef2", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "status": "ACTIVE", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "1557208f-5c23-4537-a9f2-52a69db38d3a", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "badc9861-9f68-448d-9f48-7acdcd753208", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } }, { "id": "a7f78b7c-6282-4b34-8060-693f2b67ef6b", "status": "BUILD", "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 100 } } ] } } -------------- Delete Cluster -------------- Request:: HTTP Method. Route: DELETE /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters/<cluster_id> Response:: { } HTTP 202 (Empty body) ------------------------- Configuration for Cluster ------------------------- Including a configuration-group in create-cluster will not be supported in the first public iteration, nor will attaching one post-creation to a cluster or an instance in a cluster. The cluster_name will be set in /etc/cassandra/cassandra.yaml Seeds(ip address of each node) will be set in /etc/cassandra/cassandra.yaml Endpoint snitch will be used by the default For more info see deployment docs above ------------------ Supported versions ------------------ 1.x.x - 2.x.x Internal API ------------ From API service to Taskmanager service - create_cluster Guest Agent ----------- To accomplish clustering for Cassandra datastore next RPC API are needed - prepare (already exists) - sets up datastore instance - apply overrides (already exists) - applies rendered configuration template to each node All needed functionality will be re-used Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee:: Launchpad: dmakogon IRC: denis_makogon Email: dmakogon@mirantis.com Milestones ---------- "Kilo-1" - "Kilo-2" Work Items ---------- 1. Implement API strategy. 2. Implement Taskmanager strategy. 3. Implement Guestagent strategy. Dependencies ============ To improve Cassndra initial provisioning procedure and avoid temporary SHUTDOWN state given fix must be merged fix for Cassandra manager datastore status definition https://review.openstack.org/#/c/107100/ Testing ======= For the initial implementation only unit tests would be proposed since clustering tests implementation is driven by:: - Auston McReynolds - Mat Lowery Once clustering tests are in we might consider to use them at the gate over infra resources. Documentation Impact ==================== Doc impact will appear to take its place. See Configuration Impact section. References ========== None

commit_message:
Fix incremental backups feature validation

Reasons:
 - Not all strategies have incremental backup strategy.
   Existing example: MySQLDump.
   Future: CbBackup, MongoDump, NodetoolSnapshot.

Changes:
 - incremental backups feature validation stage added;
 - refactoring validate_can_perform_action method of Backup class
 - adding fix to fake guest to prevent fake-mode tests failure;
 - unit tests proposed.

Behaviour:
 - server side will raise DatastoreOptionNotSupported,
   it fits perfectly to existing implementation;
 - from client perspective this error will interpreted
   as HTTP NotImplemented(501).

Change-Id: Ib6140f16be44a79c4bbad1a368b33d76ac3e873a
Closes-Bug: #1340175
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/19/130519/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def validate_can_perform_incremental_backup(cls, instance, operation, parent): """ Raises exception if backup incremental strategy is not supported """ datastore_cfg = CONF.get(instance.datastore_version.manager) if datastore_cfg: if not datastore_cfg.get( 'backup_incremental_strategy').get(parent.backup_type): raise exception.DatastoreOperationNotSupported( operation=operation, datastore=instance.datastore.name) @classmethod cls.validate_can_perform_incremental_backup( instance_model, "incremental_backup", _parent)

commit_message:
Added Oracle 12c support spec

Partially Implements: blueprint oracle-db-over-fedora-20

Change-Id: I7112330875c40bb6053e0ac09ec6398ac9126308
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/67/122767/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. =============================================== Support single instance OracleDB over Fedora 20 =============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/oracle-db-over-fedora-20 Since Trove aims to become production-grade DBaaS its abilities should meet market needs. Oracle Announces General Availability of Oracle Database 12c, the First Database Designed for the Cloud. Riyaj Shamsudeen says Oracle 12c pluggable databases bring a new level of efficiency and ease to database consolidation, while a wealth of other new features address performance, availability, and more. John Foley, director, strategic communications, for Oracle Corp. says Oracle Database 12c is designed for providing database as a service (DBaaS). One of the tools that facilitates that is Oracle Enterprise Manager Cloud Control, which automates database provisioning and includes a self-service portal that lets developers and users request database instances. Other cloud-enabling capabilities include database resource management, so cloud services can be delivered within minimum and maximum thresholds, and data isolation, for security within a multitenant cloud environment. Oracle Database 12c is equally well suited for public and private clouds. See more information at:: http://goo.gl/Oxg3Ur (Oracle Corp) http://goo.gl/cI5n67 (InfoWorld) http://goo.gl/3yMuRX (Forbes) Problem description =================== Oracle is the one of the oldest vendors of enterprise databases. To meet market need within OpenStack services Trove must support first-class cloud database - Oracle 12c Proposed change =============== Supported features ------------------ For initial implementation Oracle 12 would cover only regular cases. With respect to datastore compatibility matrix, Oracle 12c support will include(regular):: launch reboot terminate resize backup restore With respect to datastore compatibility matrix, Oracle 12c support will include(advanced feature):: clustering With respect to datastore compatibility matrix, Oracle 12c support will NOT include:: users API databases API root API replication To support Oracle 12c by Trove next changes should be added:: "guestagent manager" - handles deployment and management of Oracle 12c instance "backup strategy" - handles backuping/restoring procedure for Oracle 12c instance Configuration ------------- Each datastore requires its own configuration group. Next options should be added to cover needed configurations:: tcp_ports upd_ports backup_strategy replication_strategy replication_user replication_password mount_point usage_timeout backup_namespace restore_namespace volume_support device_path backup_incremental_strategy Database -------- None Public API ---------- None Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- None Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee:: Launchpad: dmakogon IRC: denis_makogon Email: dmakogon@mirantis.com Milestones ---------- "Kilo-2" Work Items ---------- List of items to develop:: DIB elements development guestagent manager development backup/restore feature development Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Oracle 12c support will include:: unit testing int testing Supported platforms ------------------- Oracle 12c can only be tested with Fedora 20(pretty close to Oracle VM/Linux). Supported versions ------------------ Whole 12.x.x.x.x branch Documentation Impact ==================== DocImpact will take its place, see Configuration impact section. References ========== Oracle 12c documentation http://docs.oracle.com/database/121/index.htm Oracle 12c feature list http://www.oracle-base.com/articles/12c/articles-12c.php

commit_message:
Add datastore and version validation step for replica provisioning

Reasons:
 - Since slave is being provisioned by POST
   against /instances/ Trove should validate
   that replica datastore and version matching
   root replica's source datastore and version.

Changes:
 - validation added;
 - int/unit tests were proposed.
 - minor fixes of example generator
 - updates API samples
 - doc note about running API example generator

Change-Id: I3dace3e514a3f767805a49d49a11c443b7510659
Closes-Bug: #1357709
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/79/119079/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuidfrom mock import patchfrom trove.common import exception from trove.common.context import TroveContext from trove.datastore import models as datastore_modelsfrom trove.tests.unittests.util import util class TestReplicationAPI(TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestReplicationAPI, self).setUp() util.init_db() self.context = Mock(spec=TroveContext) self.name = 'new_one' self.flavor_id = 2 self.image_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.databases = [] self.users = [] self.mysql_datastore_version_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.redis_datastore_version_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.mysql_datastore = datastore_models.DBDatastore() self.redis_datastore = datastore_models.DBDatastore() self.mysql_datastore.update( id=str(uuid.uuid4()), name='mysql', default_version_id=self.mysql_datastore_version_id, ) self.redis_datastore.update( id=str(uuid.uuid4()), name='redis', default_version_id=self.redis_datastore_version_id, ) self.mysql_datastore_version = datastore_models.DBDatastoreVersion() self.redis_datastore_version = datastore_models.DBDatastoreVersion() self.mysql_datastore_version.update( id=self.mysql_datastore_version_id, manager='mysql', image_id="UUID", active=1, name='5.5', datastore_id=self.mysql_datastore.id ) self.redis_datastore_version.update( id=self.redis_datastore_version_id, manager='redis', image_id="UUID", active=1, name='2.9', datastore_id=self.redis_datastore.id ) self.volume_size = 2 self.backup_id = None self.root_replica = Mock(spec=Instance) self.root_replica.id = str(uuid.uuid4()) self.root_replica.datastore = self.mysql_datastore self.root_replica.datastore_version = self.mysql_datastore_version self.real_redis_repl_strategy = CONF.get('redis').replication_strategy CONF.get('redis').replication_strategy = "Something" def tearDown(self): super(TestReplicationAPI, self).tearDown() CONF.get('redis').replication_strategy = self.real_redis_repl_strategy def test_read_replica_provisioning_with_different_datastore(self): with patch.object(Instance, 'load', return_value=self.root_replica): self.assertRaises(exception.RootReplicaDatastoreVersionMismatch, Instance.create, self.context, self.name, self.flavor_id, self.image_id, self.databases, self.users, self.redis_datastore, self.redis_datastore_version, self.volume_size, self.backup_id, slave_of_id=self.root_replica.id )

subject: Fix Cassandra service status definition
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-15 16:03:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/044094c423e3db47f5e21939c1aa719a89c39726', 'message': 'Fix Cassandra service status definition

Reasons:
 - At slow environment (small flavors, etc.),
   for certain reasons Cassandra instances are in SHUTDOWN state
   for short period of time. This issue breaks assertion
   in int-test that waits for guest to reach ACTIVE state.
 - periodic task was trying to define instance status
   before Cassandra was up and ready.

Changes:
 - timeout at start_db added;
 - polling mechanism added (verifies that all transport services
   are up and ready, if they were enabled);

Change-Id: If50c1a2fd8778e2472a1266817a42d5c3c73d8b6
Closes-Bug: #1314980

Closes-Bug: #1314980

commit_message:
Fix Cassandra service status definition

Reasons:
 - At slow environment (small flavors, etc.),
   for certain reasons Cassandra instances hitting SHUTDOWN state
   for short period of time. This issue breaks assertion
   in int-test that waits for guest to reach ACTIVE state.
 - periodic task was trying to define instance status
   before Cassandra was up and ready.

Changes:
 - extending service status definition mechanism
   for _get_actual_db_status
   (verifies that all transport services
   are up and ready, if they were enabled);

Change-Id: If50c1a2fd8778e2472a1266817a42d5c3c73d8b6
Closes-Bug: #1314980

added_lines: cassandra_conf = None def read(self): LOG.info(_("Opening cassandra.yaml")) with open(system.CASSANDRA_CONF, 'r') as config: LOG.info(_("Preparing YAML object from cassandra.yaml")) yamled = yaml.load(config.read()) return yamled def get_enabled_transport_services(self): conf = self.read_conf() thrift_enabled = conf.get('start_rpc') LOG.info(_("Thrift enabled: %s") % thrift_enabled) cql_enabled = conf.get('start_native_transport') LOG.info(_("CQL enabled: %s") % cql_enabled) return thrift_enabled, cql_enabled def _verify_cassandra_started(self): thrift, cql = self.get_enabled_transport_services() cql_running, thrift_running = False, False # Native transport service (CQL) starts slowly # than RPC transport service (Thrift) if cql: cql_out, cql_err = utils.execute_with_timeout( system.CQL_TRANSPORT_STATUS, shell=True, check_exit_code=[1, 0], timeout=100) cql_running = True if not cql_err else False LOG.debug("CQL status %s" % cql_running) if thrift: thrift_out, thrift_err = utils.execute_with_timeout( system.THRIFT_TRANSPORT_STATUS, shell=True, check_exit_code=[1, 0], timeout=100) thrift_running = True if not thrift_err else False LOG.debug("Thrift status %s" % thrift_running) # possibly previous execs were finished with code 1, # that's why guest should verify that Cassandra # actually starting in a background - # guest should check if Cassandra transports # were enabled and started or at least starting services_were_started = ( (cql_running and cql) and (thrift_running and thrift)) return services_were_started utils.poll_until( self._verify_cassandra_started, time_out=system.INSTALL_TIMEOUT, sleep_time=5) except exception.ProcessExecutionError as ex: LOG.debug(str(ex)) def read_conf(self, reload_conf=False): if not self.cassandra_conf or reload_conf: self.cassandra_conf = self.read() return self.cassandra_conf out, err = utils.execute_with_timeout( system.CQL_TRANSPORT_STATUS, shell=True)

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2015-03-01 09:32:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/364f4c3ae5fc31c651a40a08d726018b2293a7de', 'message': 'EC: Multi-phase commit conversation for PUTs

For erasure-coded PUTs, object servers have a requirement to keep
the previous version of .data file for an object around, in case
the most recent PUT for that object (in case of object-overwrite,
for instance) didn't complete successfully on a quorum of nodes.
The reconstructor eventually will clean up the old .data files
after confirming a successful PUT.

The object server/reconstructor needs a mechanism to tell if a set
of EC fragment archives constitute a successful/durable PUT for an
object.  Multi-phase commit conversation as implemented by this
patch is a solution.  Basic flow looks like:

 * proxy server erasure codes and streams the object fragments to
   (ec_ndata + ec_nparity) object servers
 * object servers store objects as EC archives and upon finishing
   object data/metadata write, send a 1st-phase response to proxy
 * upon quorum of object server responses, the proxy initiates
   2nd-phase by sending "commit" confirmations to object servers
 * upon receipt of commit message, object servers store a 0-byte
   data file as '<timestamp>.durable' indicating successful PUT,
   and send a final response to the proxy server
 * proxy waits for a minimal number (2) of object servers to
   respond with a success (2xx) status before responding to the
   client with a successful status

The multi-phase conversation is implemented via MIME documents
which provides us the ability to keep within the WSGI semantics
and handle both phases of PUT in a single HTTP transaction.  We
use 100-continue responses as a machanism to signal the end of
phase1/successful object data/metadata write to the proxy server.

Example conversation on the wire:

  proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
         Transfer-Encoding': 'chunked'
         Expect': '100-continue'
         X-Backend-Obj-Multiphase-Commit: yes

  obj:   100 Continue
         X-Obj-Multiphase-Commit: yes

  proxy: --MIMEboundary
         X-Document: object body
         <obj_data>\r\n
         --MIMEboundary

  obj:   100 Continue

  <quorum>
  proxy: X-Document: put commit
         commit_confirmation
         --boundary123--

  <object server writes ts.durable state>
  obj:   20x

  <upon receiving >=2 20x responses>
  proxy: 20x -> client

UpgradeImpact
Implements: blueprint ec-proxy-work
Change-Id: Id05593b4fa7a393d62a96f8c1627383a8e0b0340

commit_message:
EC: Multi-phase commit conversation for PUTs

For erasure-coded PUTs, object servers have a requirement to keep
the previous version of .data file for an object around, in case
the most recent PUT for that object (in case of object-overwrite,
for instance) didn't complete successfully on a quorum of nodes.
The reconstructor eventually will clean up the old .data files
after confirming a successful PUT.

The object server/reconstructor needs a mechanism to tell if a set
of EC fragment archives constitute a successful/durable PUT for an
object.  Multi-phase commit conversation as implemented by this
patch is a solution.  Basic flow looks like:

 * proxy server erasure codes and streams the object fragments to
   (ec_ndata + ec_nparity) object servers
 * object servers store objects as EC archives and upon finishing
   object data/metadata write, send a 1st-phase response to proxy
 * upon quorum of object server responses, the proxy initiates
   2nd-phase by sending "commit" confirmations to object servers
 * upon receipt of commit message, object servers store a 0-byte
   data file as '<timestamp>.durable' indicating successful PUT,
   and send a final response to the proxy server
 * proxy waits for a minimal number (2) of object servers to
   respond with a success (2xx) status before responding to the
   client with a successful status

The multi-phase conversation is implemented via MIME documents
which provides us the ability to keep within the WSGI semantics
and handle both phases of PUT in a single HTTP transaction.  We
use 100-continue responses as a machanism to signal the end of
phase1/successful object data/metadata write to the proxy server.

Example conversation on the wire:

  proxy: PUT /p/a/c/o
         Transfer-Encoding': 'chunked'
         Expect': '100-continue'
         X-Backend-Obj-Multiphase-Commit: yes

  obj:   100 Continue
         X-Obj-Multiphase-Commit: yes

  proxy: --MIMEboundary
         X-Document: object body

         <obj_data>

         --MIMEboundary
         X-Document: object metadata
         Content-MD5: <footer_meta_cksum>

         <footer_meta>

         --MIMEboundary

  <object server writes data, metadata>

  obj:   100 Continue

  <quorum>

  proxy: X-Document: put commit

         commit_confirmation

         --MIMEboundary--

  <object server writes ts.durable state>

  obj:   20x

  <proxy waits to receive >=2 2xx responses>

  proxy: 2xx -> client

Note: This patch extends DiskFile and DiskFileWriter APIs for
.durable state file manipulation.  New functions:
  DiskFileWriter::write_durable_timestamp(timestamp)
  DiskFile::is_durable()

UpgradeImpact
Implements: blueprint ec-proxy-work
Change-Id: Id05593b4fa7a393d62a96f8c1627383a8e0b0340

subject: Support full backup/restore for Cassandra
commit_message:
Support full backup/restore for Cassandra

Reasons:
 - backup/restore are significant
   features for database management;

Changes:
 - adding required configurations for resolving
   backup/restore strategy and its namespaces;
 - adding backup/restore implementations;
 - updating discovery mechanism;
 - adding oslo-group attribute to distinct
   backup implementations, to keep code
   clean and improve readabilitily;
 - unit/int tests proposed.

DocImpact: added configuration options backup/restore namespaces and
           backup_strategy for Cassandra datastore.

Implements: blueprint cassandra-backup-restore

Change-Id: I6da2cf726bdb4ab2b969b745f32429e3b2c98bdb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/51/77551/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fuel plugin for Group Based Policy

Creates a new stackforge project to host the Fuel
plugin for Group Based Policy.

commit_message:
Fixed links in multi-server Swift documentation

The link to the ubuntu installation guide was incorrect and 404'ing.

This change updates page to point (anchor) to the install guide
section of docs.openstack.org, so it will always point to the latest
versions of the install documentation.

It also updates the deep links to the current install guides for the
past few releases.

As links continue to get outdated or we forget to add new ones, the
anchor link at the top of the page will probably still work.

Change-Id: I38299c03370936eb41992a953aa9d10b01a8396b
Closes-Bug: #1147331

added_lines: def get_flow_details(self, fd_uuid): try: flowdetails = self._tables.flowdetails with self._engine.begin() as conn: q = (sql.select([flowdetails]). where(flowdetails.c.uuid == fd_uuid)) row = conn.execute(q).first() if not row: raise exc.NotFound("No flow details found with uuid" " '%s'" % fd_uuid) return self._converter.convert_flow_detail(row) except sa_exc.SQLAlchemyError as e: raise exc.StorageFailure("Failed getting flow details with" " uuid '%s'" % fd_uuid, e) def get_atom_details(self, ad_uuid): try: atomdetails = self._tables.atomdetails with self._engine.begin() as conn: q = (sql.select([atomdetails]). where(atomdetails.c.uuid == ad_uuid)) row = conn.execute(q).first() if not row: raise exc.NotFound("No atom details found with uuid" " '%s'" % ad_uuid) return self._converter.convert_atom_detail(row) except sa_exc.SQLAlchemyError as e: raise exc.StorageFailure("Failed getting atom details with" " uuid '%s'" % ad_uuid, e)

commit_message:
Provide more contextual information about invalid periodics

Instead of just telling the user of the periodic worker that
certain callbacks were invalid tell the user which callback
was invalid and exactly what attributes were expected but were
not found. This makes the errors that much easier to diagnose
and to resolve.

Change-Id: Iaf8caf5e460e3ff4731ef575e924c9b86a9d5ae1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/20/159020/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix lookup scoping multi-match ordering

When look-up is occurring the possible provider
ordering is used instead of the scope returned provider
ordering. This causes incorrect matches when look-up
argument names that are produced by multiple providers (at
the same scope level) all providing the same requirement
name.

The scope order should be enforced as the de-facto order
and not the order that the storage unit finds (which is
hash based and varies depending on hash ordering).

Closes-Bug: #1425326

Change-Id: I15f1ee5515758bdc470c0f7dd7a2f616923e5628
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/56/158956/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def look_for(haystack, needles, extractor=None): """Find items in haystack and returns matches found (in haystack order). Given a list of items (the haystack) and a list of items to look for (the needles) this will look for the needles in the haystack and returns the found needles (if any). The ordering of the returned needles is in the order they are located in the haystack. Example input and output: >>> from taskflow.utils import misc >>> hay = [3, 2, 1] >>> misc.look_for(hay, [1, 2]) [2, 1] """ if extractor is None: extractor = lambda v: v matches = [] for i, v in enumerate(needles): try: matches.append((haystack.index(extractor(v)), i)) except ValueError: pass if not matches: return [] else: return [needles[i] for (_hay_i, i) in sorted(matches)]

commit_message:
Property exception message doesn't has resource name prefix

When an unknown property is provided in the heat template,
heat raise an exception as below:

Unknown Property <prp-name>

To avoid the confusion if a template has multiple resources
with same named property, its fixed to report as below

Unknown Property <resource name>: <prp-name>

Change-Id: Id5eb557da9784ec0429bf1c5b246556dd92dfd6b
Closes-bug: #1425795

commit_message:
Metadata multivalue operators support

Corresponding blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/metadata-multivalue-operators-support

Change-Id: Ia51fad2b317bb71f64a743946e65b66f11bfddb8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/64/147264/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================================== Support for multivalue operators in metadata catalog ==================================================== Metadata catalog provides data that user can pin to resources, e.g. flavors extra specs. This will be used by scheduler to choose host that satisfies requirements provided in extra specs. Nova scheduler implements operators to combine multiple values under one key in extra specs: <or> and <all-in>. Unfortunately catalog does not provide which operator is suitable for given property. This blueprint aims at this problem by extending current jsons with suitable operators for each property. Problem description =================== There is work being done in Horizon to make multivalue support for single key in extra specs, however Glance currently does not provide information which operators are suitable for given property. For example in compute-host-capabilities.json there is property called cpu_info:features. For this property both operators can be used: <all-in> and <or>. However if we think of a cpu_info:model property, then only <or> operator makes sense. Proposed change =============== To make end-user (e.g. Horizon) aware which operator can be used for given property, this blueprint extends existing properties (and also properties inside objects) with a new section under key - "operator": For example, current property: "cpu_info:vendor": { "title": "Vendor", "description": "Specifies the CPU manufacturer.", "type": "string", "enum": [ "Intel", "AMD" ] }, And after extension: "cpu_info:vendor": { "title": "Vendor", "description": "Specifies the CPU manufacturer.", "operator": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "<or>" ] }, "type": "string", "enum": [ "Intel", "AMD" ] }, The added section is: "operator": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "<or>", "<all-in>" ] }, This section will be optional, e.g. property that is integer does not need operator. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- This will not impact data model, because "operator" will be part of json schema which is under one column in database. REST API impact --------------- Example extended GET object body: { "objects": [ { "name": "object1", "namespace": "my-namespace", "description": "my-description", "properties": { "prop1": { "title": "My Property", "description": "More info here", "operator": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "<all-in>" ] }, "type": "string", "readonly": true, } } } ], "first": "/v2/metadefs/objects?limit=1", "next": "/v2/metadefs/objects?marker=object1&limit=1", "schema": "/v2/schema/metadefs/objects" } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Upgrade of jsons or database in existing OpenStack installation will not be needed. "operator" section will not be mandatory so the installation can keep running without upgrade. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pawel-koniszewski Other contributors: None Reviewers --------- None Work Items ---------- * Extend existing metadata jsons with operator section. * Extend API json schema with new option Dependencies ============ Horizon blueprint that depends on this blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/metadata-widget-multivalue-selection Nova blueprint that this blueprint depends on: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-all-in-list-operator-to-extra-spec-ops Testing ======= Current unit tests and functional tests will be extended to make sure that the new section is returned and that it is correct. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-16 00:03:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e75f310e8d57b8edd0e9709843f5bae0febf0585', 'message': "Add a custom pylint check for oslo i18n and logging

This change adds a new pylint test capable of detecting numerous
violations of OpenStack i18n policies:

- Incorrectly marked severities:
    LOG.info(_LE('error or info?'))
- Logging that is not marked for translation:
    LOG.info('untranslated')
- Over-eager interpolation:
    LOG.info(_LI('foo: %s') % 'bar')
- Concatenating translated literals:
    _('foo') + 'bar'
- Using more than one positional argument in a translated message:
    _('Found %s in %s')
- Using translation marker on something other than a string literal:
    msg = 'Error'; _(msg)
- Performs existing pylint format checks on OpenStack logging calls:
    LOG.info(_('%(a)s but %(b)s is missing', {'a': 'foo'}))

    LOG.info(_('foo'))

portion of the codebase, they can experiment with enabling
log-i18n-default)

A significant feature of this check over the existing pep8/hackng checks
is that in many cases it is also able to trace values through
intermediate lines of code.  In particular, it can handle many variants
of this common OpenStack idiom:

    msg = _('failed')
    logging.info(msg)
    raise msg

commit_message:
Add a custom pylint check for oslo i18n and logging

This change adds a new pylint test capable of detecting numerous
violations of OpenStack i18n policies:

- Incorrectly marked severities:
    LOG.info(_LE('error or info?'))
- Logging that is not marked for translation:
    LOG.info('untranslated')
- Over-eager interpolation:
    LOG.info(_LI('foo: %s') % 'bar')
- Concatenating translated literals:
    _('foo') + 'bar'
- Using more than one positional argument in a translated message:
    _('Found %s in %s')
- Using translation marker on something other than a string literal:
    msg = 'Error'; _(msg)
- Performs existing pylint format checks on OpenStack logging calls:
    LOG.info(_('%(a)s but %(b)s is missing', {'a': 'foo'}))
- Logging messages not marked with explicit severity:
    LOG.info(_('foo'))

(This change disables the last one mentioned above as the migration to
_LI/_LE/etc is far from complete.  If anyone wants to check their
portion of the codebase, they can experiment with enabling
log-i18n-default)

A significant feature of this check over the existing pep8/hackng checks
is that in many cases it is also able to trace values through
intermediate lines of code.  In particular, it can handle many variants
of this common OpenStack idiom:

    msg = _('failed')
    logging.info(msg)
    raise msg

Change-Id: I319632204663f3e5640133145dd0cd60733c6c11

commit_message:
Fixes test_multiple_filters filters definition

This test contained an invalid filter, which was
simply being ignored by both driver and
controller.

This patch fixes this bug and add a test to show
invalid filters are ignored.

Closes-Bug: #1424749

Change-Id: I05ab123717b49bcb47ca676e55040818c1451d71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/11/158411/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: my_url = '/domains?enabled&name=%s' % self.domainA['name'] self.assertTrue(r.result.get('domains')[0]['enabled']) def test_invalid_filter_is_ignored(self): """GET /domains?enableds&name=myname Test Plan: - Update policy for no protection on api - Filter by name and 'enableds', which does not exist - Assert 'enableds' is ignored """ new_policy = {"identity:list_domains": []} self._set_policy(new_policy) my_url = '/domains?enableds=0&name=%s' % self.domainA['name'] r = self.get(my_url, auth=self.auth) id_list = self._get_id_list_from_ref_list(r.result.get('domains')) # domainA is returned and it is enabled, since enableds=0 is not the # same as enabled=0 self.assertEqual(len(id_list), 1) self.assertIn(self.domainA['id'], id_list) self.assertTrue(r.result.get('domains')[0]['enabled'])
deleted_lines: my_url = '/domains?enableds&name=%s' % self.domainA['name']

commit_message:
Limit WorkflowExecution.state_info size.

This fixes a bug when workflow execution fails due to large output,
and failure handler can't update DB because state_info field is
too big. Good against DOS attacks, too.

Change-Id: I37103bac445dbcef49c6bfe6869a9ebd6938c86d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/03/160303/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

WorkflowExecution.state_info, 'set', lambda t, v, o, i: utils.cut(v, 1020), retval=True )
deleted_lines: state_info = sa.Column(sa.Text(), nullable=True)

commit_message:
Always load revocation manager

The revocation manager should be loaded automatically as part of
the ongoing work to replace the concept of extensions.

Closes-Bug: #1427440

Change-Id: Ie9fb779198d30eb3ff81207c977bafdcd4453f5f

commit_message:
Utility for database migration.

The DB migration often needs to clone a table into a new one as
databases like sqlite do not support most of the ALTER commands for
in-place modification of table schema. This utility has method to clone
a table to new one so that a new table can be created and data migrated
to it for handling migration. This is fairly generic, therefore new file
is added.

New generic functions can be added here when needed.

Co-Authored-By: Visnusaran Murugan <visnusaran.murugan@hp.com>

Change-Id: I229907dc2cab618ca5c76a72956ce8c5f49a2127
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/43/159443/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # SQLAlchemy helper functions import sqlalchemy def clone_table(name, parent, meta, newcols=[], ignorecols=[], swapcols={}): """ helper function that clones parent table schema onto new table. :param name: new table name :param parent: parent table to copy schema from :param newcols: list of new column names to be added :param ignorecols: list of column names to be ignored while cloning :param swapcols: alternative column schema :return: sqlalchemy.Table instance """ cols = [c.copy() for c in parent.columns if c.name not in ignorecols if c.name not in swapcols] cols.extend(swapcols.values()) cols.extend(newcols) constraints = [c.copy() for c in parent.constraints] return sqlalchemy.Table(name, meta, *(cols + constraints))

commit_message:
Move software service logic to own module

The size of EngineService is starting to affect maintainability.
This change creates service_software_config.SoftwareConfigService
and moves all the software config service method implementations
into it.

Software config calls to EngineService are delegated to
SoftwareConfigService. Unit tests remain in test_engine_service to
include the EngineService entrypoint methods in the test coverage.

Change-Id: Icf51dfd35423ac33a9126731862a90525c17306c
Related-Blueprint: software-config-trigger

sort the configs by config name, to give the list of metadata a # deterministic and controllable order. all_sd_s = sorted(all_sd, key=lambda sd: sd.config.name) result = [api.format_software_config(sd.config) for sd in all_sd_s] return result def _push_metadata_software_deployments(self, cnxt, server_id): rs = db_api.resource_get_by_physical_resource_id(cnxt, server_id) if not rs: return deployments = self.metadata_software_deployments(cnxt, server_id) md = rs.rsrc_metadata or {} md['deployments'] = deployments rs.update_and_save({'rsrc_metadata': md}) metadata_put_url = None for rd in rs.data: if rd.key == 'metadata_put_url': metadata_put_url = rd.value break if metadata_put_url: json_md = jsonutils.dumps(md) requests.put(metadata_put_url, json_md) def _refresh_software_deployment(self, cnxt, sd, deploy_signal_id): container, object_name = urlparse.urlparse( deploy_signal_id).path.split('/')[-2:] swift_plugin = cnxt.clients.client_plugin('swift') swift = swift_plugin.client() try: headers = swift.head_object(container, object_name) except Exception as ex: # ignore not-found, in case swift is not consistent yet if swift_plugin.is_not_found(ex): LOG.info(_LI('Signal object not found: %(c)s %(o)s') % { 'c': container, 'o': object_name}) return sd raise ex lm = headers.get('last-modified') last_modified = swift_plugin.parse_last_modified(lm) prev_last_modified = sd.updated_at if prev_last_modified: # assume stored as utc, convert to offset-naive datetime prev_last_modified = prev_last_modified.replace(tzinfo=None) if prev_last_modified and (last_modified <= prev_last_modified): return sd try: (headers, obj) = swift.get_object(container, object_name) except Exception as ex: # ignore not-found, in case swift is not consistent yet if swift_plugin.is_not_found(ex): LOG.info(_LI( 'Signal object not found: %(c)s %(o)s') % { 'c': container, 'o': object_name}) return sd raise ex if obj: self.signal_software_deployment( cnxt, sd.id, json.loads(obj), timeutils.strtime(last_modified)) return db_api.software_deployment_get(cnxt, sd.id) sd = db_api.software_deployment_get(cnxt, deployment_id) if sd.status == rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_IN_PROGRESS: c = sd.config.config input_values = dict((i['name'], i['value']) for i in c['inputs']) transport = input_values.get('deploy_signal_transport') if transport == 'TEMP_URL_SIGNAL': sd = self._refresh_software_deployment( cnxt, sd, input_values.get('deploy_signal_id')) return api.format_software_deployment(sd) sd = db_api.software_deployment_create(cnxt, { 'config_id': config_id, 'server_id': server_id, 'input_values': input_values, 'tenant': cnxt.tenant_id, 'stack_user_project_id': stack_user_project_id, 'action': action, 'status': status, 'status_reason': status_reason}) self._push_metadata_software_deployments(cnxt, server_id) return api.format_software_deployment(sd) if not deployment_id: raise ValueError(_('deployment_id must be specified')) sd = db_api.software_deployment_get(cnxt, deployment_id) status = sd.status if not status == rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_IN_PROGRESS: # output values are only expected when in an IN_PROGRESS state return details = details or {} output_status_code = rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_OUTPUT_STATUS_CODE ov = sd.output_values or {} status = None status_reasons = {} status_code = details.get(output_status_code) if status_code and str(status_code) != '0': status = rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_FAILED status_reasons[output_status_code] = _( 'Deployment exited with non-zero status code: %s' ) % details.get(output_status_code) event_reason = 'deployment failed (%s)' % status_code else: event_reason = 'deployment succeeded' for output in sd.config.config['outputs'] or []: out_key = output['name'] if out_key in details: ov[out_key] = details[out_key] if output.get('error_output', False): status = rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_FAILED status_reasons[out_key] = details[out_key] event_reason = 'deployment failed' for out_key in rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_OUTPUTS: ov[out_key] = details.get(out_key) if status == rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_FAILED: # build a status reason out of all of the values of outputs # flagged as error_output status_reasons = [' : '.join((k, six.text_type(status_reasons[k]))) for k in status_reasons] status_reason = ', '.join(status_reasons) else: status = rpc_api.SOFTWARE_DEPLOYMENT_COMPLETE status_reason = _('Outputs received') self.update_software_deployment( cnxt, deployment_id=deployment_id, output_values=ov, status=status, status_reason=status_reason, config_id=None, input_values=None, action=None, # Return a string describing the outcome of handling the signal data return event_reason update_data = {} if config_id: update_data['config_id'] = config_id if input_values: update_data['input_values'] = input_values if output_values: update_data['output_values'] = output_values if action: update_data['action'] = action if status: update_data['status'] = status if status_reason: update_data['status_reason'] = status_reason if updated_at: update_data['updated_at'] = timeutils.normalize_time( timeutils.parse_isotime(updated_at)) else: update_data['updated_at'] = timeutils.utcnow() sd = db_api.software_deployment_update(cnxt, deployment_id, update_data) # only push metadata if this update resulted in the config_id # changing, since metadata is just a list of configs if config_id: self._push_metadata_software_deployments(cnxt, sd.server_id) return api.format_software_deployment(sd) db_api.software_deployment_delete(cnxt, deployment_id)

There are huge numbers of tests where we patch validate methods for

commit_message:
Patch validate methods with mock instead of mox

There are huge numbers of tests where we patch validate methods for
constraints. Currently we use for it mox, but it requires us to add
ReplayAll and VerifyAll in tests, where we use mock. So let's teach it
to use mock, it should make easier migration on mock in the future.

Change-Id: Ia82b3507b8699ffa0db20bd3c24279263ff9cc4b

commit_message:
add profile tool

this adds a profile tool that lets you profile a unit test run for a
portion of the tree. yappi is supposed to handle eventlet in it's
current release, though it's some times unclear in looking at the data.

Change-Id: I01171c6d74c3b1897a6f63c2ad71fccdbc9d6fae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/138440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # # Copyright 2014 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import cProfile import functools import os import pstats import StringIO import sys import testtools def main(argv): dirname = argv[1] print("Profiling %s" % dirname) os.chdir(dirname) pr = cProfile.Profile() pr.enable() testtools.run.TestProgram( argv=['discover'], testRunner=functools.partial( testtools.run.TestToolsTestRunner, stdout=sys.stdout), stdout=sys.stdout, exit=False) pr.disable() s = StringIO.StringIO() sortby = 'cumulative' ps = pstats.Stats(pr, stream=s).sort_stats(sortby) print("Dumping profile stats to profile.out") ps.dump_stats('profile.out') return 0 if __name__ == '__main__': sys.exit(main(sys.argv))

commit_message:
Add new policy rule for EC2 get_password_data

This patch adds new policy rule for EC2 get_password_data.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy
DocImpact

Change-Id: Idee9062a64235402969b2e4e7de4bcbd374aa487

commit_message:
Cinder objects base

This patch is to insert the objects code base, currently based
on nova.objects.  It will be later based on
oslo_versionedobjects once it is available.  This is done
to make progress on changing cinder internals to use objects,
since nova.objects and oslo.versionedobjects are similar.

Inserted objects code base into cinder and modified cinder services
to use object-aware serializer.

Change-Id: I42a6cc43da19ca29db4cfb33cbf794afed18f758
Implements: blueprint cinder-objects

deleted_lines: target.update(target_obj or {}) if context.is_admin and context.project_id != volume['project_id']: project_id = volume['project_id'] volume_id = volume['id'] if not volume['host']: reserve_opts = {'volumes': -1, 'gigabytes': -volume['size']} volume['volume_type_id']) self.db.volume_destroy(context.elevated(), volume_id) if not force and volume['status'] not in ["available", "error", "error_restoring", "error_extending"]: "but current status is: %s") % volume['status'] if volume['attach_status'] == "attached": if volume['migration_status'] is not None: self.db.volume_update(context, volume_id, {'status': 'deleting', 'terminated_at': now})

subject: Rename "Keystone LightWeight Tokens" (KLWT) to "Fernet" tokens
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-27 23:12:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/fd2ee0ff2cfc1da4a0c7455b58ab6e2799c93355', 'message': 'Rename "Keystone LightWeight Tokens" (KLWT) to "Fernet" tokens

Reasoning:

- We generally name tokens after the technology used in their transport
  format. For example, we also don't refer to UUID tokens as "UUID4
  tokens" nor PKI tokens as "JSON tokens", both of which would describe
  their payload. We also don't refer to PKI tokens as "Keystone
  HeavyWeight Tokens (KHWT)" because that would be arbitrary and
  redundant. And besides, UUID tokens are smaller ("lighter") than KLWT
  tokens anyway.

- The payload in KLWT tokens (read: Automated Teller Machine machine) is
  a MessagePacked tuple. Referring to these tokens as either
  "MessagePacked tokens" or "tuple tokens" does nothing to describe the
  end user's experience with them, and would oddly preclude other tokens
  from using the same underlying technologies. There's no reason that
  a future version of PKI tokens couldn't carry a MessagePacked payload.

- Fernet is actually a well defined specification intended for use as
  API tokens: https://github.com/fernet/spec

Change-Id: I6d7aca0ef23df6932544f5dcf6eb1fac0af012ae

commit_message:
Rename "Keystone LightWeight Tokens" (KLWT) to "Fernet" tokens

Reasoning:

- We generally name tokens after the technology used in their transport
  format. For example, we also don't refer to UUID tokens as "UUID4
  tokens" nor PKI tokens as "JSON tokens", both of which would describe
  their payload. We also don't refer to PKI tokens as "Keystone
  HeavyWeight Tokens (KHWT)" because that would be arbitrary and
  redundant. And besides, UUID tokens are smaller ("lighter") than KLWT
  tokens anyway.

- The payload in KLWT tokens (read: Automated Teller Machine machine) is
  a MessagePacked tuple. Referring to these tokens as either
  "MessagePacked tokens" or "tuple tokens" does nothing to describe the
  end user's experience with them, and would oddly preclude other tokens
  from using the same underlying technologies. There's no reason that
  a future version of PKI tokens couldn't carry a MessagePacked payload.

- Fernet is actually a well defined specification intended for use as
  API tokens: https://github.com/fernet/spec

Change-Id: I6d7aca0ef23df6932544f5dcf6eb1fac0af012ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/40/160040/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.token.providers.fernet import utils as fernetclass FernetSetup(BasePermissionsSetup): """Setup a key repository for Fernet tokens. keys (using keystone-manage fernet_rotate, for example). name = 'fernet_setup' fernet.create_key_directory(keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) if fernet.validate_key_repository(): fernet.initialize_key_repository( keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) class FernetRotate(BasePermissionsSetup): """Rotate Fernet encryption keys. This assumes you have already run keystone-manage fernet_setup. tokens. Excess active keys (beyond [fernet_tokens] max_active_keys) are Rotating keys too frequently, or with [fernet_tokens] max_active_keys set too low, will cause tokens to become invalid prior to their expiration. name = 'fernet_rotate' if fernet.validate_key_repository(): fernet.rotate_keys(keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) FernetRotate, FernetSetup,
deleted_lines: from keystone.token.providers.klwt import utils as klwtclass KLWTSetup(BasePermissionsSetup): """Setup a key repository for KLW tokens. keys (using keystone-manage klwt_rotate, for example). name = 'klwt_setup' klwt.create_key_directory(keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) if klwt.validate_key_repository(): klwt.initialize_key_repository(keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) class KLWTRotate(BasePermissionsSetup): """Rotate keys. This assumes you have already run keystone-manage klwt_setup. tokens. Excess active keys (beyond [klw_tokens] max_active_keys) are Rotating keys too frequently, or with [klw_tokens] max_active_keys set too low, will cause tokens to become invalid prior to their expiration. name = 'klwt_rotate' if klwt.validate_key_repository(): klwt.rotate_keys(keystone_user_id, keystone_group_id) KLWTRotate, KLWTSetup,

commit_message:
Add CADF notifications for trusts

Start sending CADF notfications for create and delete operations
on trusts.

Co-Authored-By: Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
partially implements bp: cadf-everywhere

Change-Id: Ib54ee98b5cb834e1a22ebb29345266194fba4d9c

commit_message:
Use mock instead of fixtures when appropriate

This patch chnages code that uses fixtures.MonkeyPatch to use mock
where possible. Also tempfile is used instead of fixtures.TempFile in
one place.

Change-Id: I739d59b8dc34e87649852d08fed7ff955b230363
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/98/159898/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time @mock.patch.object(time, 'sleep', lambda seconds: None)
deleted_lines: import fixtures def setUp(self): super(PhysicalWorkTestCase, self).setUp() def noop(*args, **kwargs): pass self.useFixture(fixtures.MonkeyPatch('time.sleep', noop))
