commit_message:
Keystone Lightweight Tokens (KLWT)

This includes a KLW token provider and keystone-manage commands to
initialize a key repository and perform key rotation.

Co-Authored-By: Dolph Mathews <dolph.mathews@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ibca4b1765d06f239df113aa3ec367e60de61a225
Implements: bp klw-tokens
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/17/145317/35 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime from oslo.utils import timeutils from keystone.token.providers.ae import token_formatters # NOTE(lbragstad): This should consist of a mapping from the # `token_version` to the object that can handle that token. This was, once # we detect what version of the token we're dealing with, we can pass the # information it's respective formatter needs to either create or validate # the token. token_format_map = {'01': token_formatters.StandardTokenFormatter()} def _convert_timestamp_to_int(self, time_string): """Convert a time formatted string to a timestamp integer. This is done because integers can be represented smaller than a string that represents a time. :param time_string: string representing the time :returns: an integer timestamp """ time_object = timeutils.parse_isotime(time_string) return int(time_object.strftime('%s')) Here is where we need to detect what is given to us, and what kind of token the user is expect. Depending on the outcome of that, we can pass all the information to be packed to the proper token format handler. :param method_names: method of authentication if (CONF.trust.enabled and not trust and metadata_ref and 'trust_id' in metadata_ref): trust = self.trust_api.get_trust(metadata_ref['trust_id']) # In this case we should pull data out of the trust and create the # token accordingly. This will also be a different token version so # that we know we are dealing with a trust authenticated token when # we go to validate. token_ref = None if auth_context and self._is_mapped_token(auth_context): token_ref = self._handle_mapped_tokens(auth_context, project_id, domain_id) token_data = self.v3_token_data_helper.get_token_data( user_id, method_names, auth_context.get('extras') if auth_context else None, domain_id=domain_id, project_id=project_id, expires=expires_at, trust=trust, bind=auth_context.get('bind') if auth_context else None, token=token_ref, include_catalog=include_catalog, audit_info=parent_audit_id) created_at_str = token_data['token']['issued_at'] issued_at_ts = self._convert_timestamp_to_int(created_at_str) expires_at_str = token_data['token']['expires_at'] expires_at_ts = self._convert_timestamp_to_int(expires_at_str) audit_ids = token_data['token']['audit_ids'] token_format = '01' # We will probably have different token formats, each with their own # create_token method. Here is where we would make the decision to # format the token one way or the other. token_id = self.token_format_map[token_format].create_token(user_id, project_id, issued_at_ts, expires_at_ts, audit_ids) return token_id, token_data
deleted_lines: :param method_names: raise exception.NotImplemented()

commit_message:
NetApp eseries implementation for manage/unmanage

This patch enables manage and unmanage support
for the eseries iscsi driver.

Implements: Blueprint eseries-manage-unmanage

Change-Id: I5a7f090300065d829bc94c81d8b976dcb541b2a0

Abstract volumes and volume snapshots into objects.
Get, create, and delete snapshot APIs were changed to
use new snapshot objects.  A skeleton volume object was
created, but cinder internals were not changed to use
the volume object, although volume is referenced and
used by the snapshot object.  The internals will be
changed to use volume object in a subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I387018e80c8539565e99454db65d976030002c0f
Implements: blueprint cinder-objects

Get, create, and delete snapshot APIs were changed to
use new snapshot objects.  A skeleton volume object was
created, but cinder internals were not changed to use

'}, {'number': 32, 'created': '2015-02-18 23:07:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/88d5ed1b400594cc36ed3a8d4a011d10a96ccd8f', 'message': 'Snapshot and volume objects

Abstract volumes and volume snapshots into objects.
Get, create, and delete snapshot APIs were changed to
use new snapshot objects.  A skeleton volume object was
created, but cinder internals were not changed to use
the volume object, although volume is referenced and

commit_message:
Snapshot and volume objects

Abstract volumes and volume snapshots into objects.
Get, create, and delete snapshot APIs were changed to
use new snapshot objects.  A skeleton volume object was
created, but cinder internals were not changed to use
the volume object, although volume is referenced and
used by the snapshot object.  The internals will be
changed to use volume object in a subsequent patch.

Change-Id: I387018e80c8539565e99454db65d976030002c0f
Implements: blueprint cinder-objects
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/66/133566/23 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.objects import base as objects_base if isinstance(target_obj, objects_base.CinderObject): # Turn object into dict so target.update can work target.update(objects_base.obj_to_primitive(target_obj) or {}) else: target.update(target_obj or {}) if not force and snapshot.status not in ["available", "error"]: "deleted together with the cgsnapshot.") % snapshot.id snapshot.status = 'deleting' snapshot.save() volume = self.db.volume_get(context, snapshot.volume_id)
deleted_lines: target.update(target_obj or {}) if not force and snapshot['status'] not in ["available", "error"]: "deleted together with the cgsnapshot.") % snapshot['id'] self.db.snapshot_update(context, snapshot['id'], {'status': 'deleting'}) volume = self.db.volume_get(context, snapshot['volume_id'])

commit_message:
Add gabbi tests to cover the SamplesController

The samples controller has only two methods, get_all and get_one. This
new yaml file makes simple queries against a suite of three samples
provided by the SampleDataFixture to validate expected behavior.

Four xfails were required to account for limitations in the framework
that supports the SampleController. Bugs have been linked from the
yaml file.

Change-Id: Ifa90d43cb43bf79c850b4d604d1ddb67a5e06d56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/45/159945/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Explore and test the samples conroller, using samples supplied by # the SampleDataFixture. # fixtures: - ConfigFixture - SampleDataFixture tests: # Confirm all the samples are there and expected requests behave. # TODO(chdent): There's a danger here that the ordering of multiple # samples will not be consistent. - name: lists samples url: /v2/samples response_headers: content-type: /application/json/ response_json_paths: $[0].meter: livestock $[0].metadata.breed: cow $[1].metadata.breed: pig $[2].metadata.breed: sheep - name: get just one url: /v2/samples/$RESPONSE['$[0].id'] response_json_paths: $.meter: livestock $.metadata.breed: cow - name: list samples with limit url: /v2/samples?limit=1 response_json_paths: $[0].meter: livestock $[0].metadata.breed: cow $[-1].metadata.breed: cow - name: list zero samples with zero limit url: /v2/samples?limit=0 response_strings: - '[]' - name: list samples with query url: /v2/samples?q.field=resource_metadata.breed&q.value=cow&q.op=eq response_json_paths: $[0].meter: livestock $[0].metadata.breed: cow $[-1].metadata.breed: cow - name: query by user url: /v2/samples?q.field=user&q.value=$RESPONSE['$[0].user_id']&q.op=eq response_json_paths: $[0].user_id: $RESPONSE['$[0].user_id'] - name: query by user_id url: /v2/samples?q.field=user_id&q.value=$RESPONSE['$[0].user_id']&q.op=eq response_json_paths: $[0].user_id: $RESPONSE['$[0].user_id'] - name: query by project url: /v2/samples?q.field=project&q.value=$RESPONSE['$[0].project_id']&q.op=eq response_json_paths: $[0].project_id: $RESPONSE['$[0].project_id'] - name: query by project_id url: /v2/samples?q.field=project_id&q.value=$RESPONSE['$[0].project_id']&q.op=eq response_json_paths: $[0].project_id: $RESPONSE['$[0].project_id'] # Explore failure modes for listing samples - name: list samples with bad field url: /v2/samples?q.field=harpoon&q.value=cow&q.op=eq status: 400 response_strings: - metaquery - unrecognized field in query - name: list samples with metaquery field url: /v2/samples?q.field=metaquery&q.value=cow&q.op=eq desc: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1426466 xfail: true status: 400 - name: bad limit value url: /v2/samples?limit=happiness status: 400 response_strings: - Invalid input for field/attribute limit - name: negative limit value 400 url: /v2/samples?limit=-99 status: 400 - name: negative limit value error message url: /v2/samples?limit=-99 desc: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1426483 xfail: true status: 400 response_headers: content-type: /application/json/ response_json_paths: $.error_message.faultstring: Limit must be positive - name: bad accept desc: try an unexpected content type url: /v2/samples request_headers: accept: text/plain status: 406 - name: complex good accept desc: client sends complex accept do we adapt url: /v2/samples request_headers: accept: text/plain, application/json; q=0.8 - name: complex bad accept desc: client sends complex accept do we adapt url: /v2/samples request_headers: accept: text/plain, application/binary; q=0.8 status: 406 - name: bad method desc: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1426476 xfail: true url: /v2/samples method: POST status: 405 # Work with just one sample. - name: list one of the samples url: /v2/samples?limit=1 - name: retrieve one sample url: /v2/samples/$RESPONSE['$[0].id'] response_headers: content-type: /application/json/ response_json_paths: $.meter: livestock - name: retrieve sample with useless query url: /v2/samples/$RESPONSE['$.id']?limit=5 status: 400 response_strings: - "Unknown argument:" - name: attempt missing sample url: /v2/samples/davesnothere desc: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1426483 xfail: true status: 404 response_headers: content-type: /application/json/ response_json_paths: $.error_message.faultstring: Sample davesnothere Not Found

commit_message:
Adding string() YAQL function registered at Mistral level

* This is a temporary fix untill we switch to YAQL 1.0 where
  this and many other functions are built-in.

Change-Id: I8b0bffcf19ec724308116ea00c23a5d22256459a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/39/160439/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: yaql_ctx.register_function(to_str, 'string') def to_str(value): return str(value())

commit_message:
Generic changes for Node Inspection

1. Adds two new fields to table ``nodes``.
2. Enable changes in conductor and api to execute
   the methods for inspection.
3. Adds the default timeout `inspect_timeout` in
   ironic.conf.sample file.
The new field 'last_inspected' has been renamed to
'inspection_finished_at' after discussion.

The ironic-client changes for 'inspect' to be
added to the list of node-set-provision-state valid
actions are being addressed by
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/148804

Implements : blueprint ironic-node-properties-discovery

DocImpact

Change-Id: If9aab90accf5a60ad3febbfc1f5d367eed987c13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/23/149823/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: | 1.22 - Added inspect_hardware method RPC_API_VERSION = '1.22' def inspect_hardware(self, context, node_id, topic=None): """Signals the conductor service to perform hardware introspection. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :param topic: RPC topic. Defaults to self.topic. :raises: InstanceHardwareIntrospectionFailure :raises: InvalidParameterValue if validation fails :raises: NoFreeConductorWorker when there is no free worker to start async task. """ cctxt = self.client.prepare(topic=topic or self.topic, version='1.22') return cctxt.call(context, 'inspect_hardware', node_id=node_id)
deleted_lines: RPC_API_VERSION = '1.21'

commit_message:
Keystone REST API single project GET

The URL regex was not including the ID capture, so actually calling
the URL via angular didn't work. This adds the ID capture.

You can manually verify it by going to with POSTMAN:

http://localhost:9000/api/keystone/projects/9e789090449f45f3aaf15823f7e2da1a

See also: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Horizon/RESTAPI

Partially Implements: blueprint instance-details-redesign

Change-Id: I83a8312e772422d96f3c7a15816c45a700e2d047
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/57/160457/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: url_regex = r'keystone/projects/(?P<id>[0-9a-f]+|default)$'
deleted_lines: url_regex = r'keystone/projects/$'

commit_message:
context['view'] not available in Serial Console

In some configurations, the Serial Console gives
a "cannot find instance" error even though the
instance is available for the given id.

See project/instances/views.py SerialConsoleView.
The problem is that it is using context['view'].request
and throwing an exception because in some configurations
context['view'] is not found. Not clear on why it is
there in some cases, e.g. in devstack dev environment.

In any event, the right way to code it is to use
self instead of context['view']. This is what
other classes do in views.py. I confirmed that
self == context['view'].

Closes-bug: #1427391

Change-Id: Ib97f874695c874eb97a5aeb6f84661e33a427477
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/20/160520/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance = api.nova.server_get(self.request, console_url = project_console.get_console(self.request,
deleted_lines: instance = api.nova.server_get(context['view'].request, console_url = project_console.get_console(context['view'].request,

commit_message:
Remove spaces from extension lists

This commit removes all of the spaces from the extension lists in the
env vars for passed into iniset. With spaces these lists are only getting
the first item set in the output tempest.conf file which means we only run
a very small subset of the tests we intend to.

Change-Id: I489f6ec4dd5b1824ebff576902746b160c6b8bc5

commit_message:
Add python-keyczar to global-requirements.py

In Keystone, we're using python-keyczar to manage keys for an authenticated
encryption token solution. The library is Apache 2.0 licensed. The project
homepage can be found at https://code.google.com/p/keyczar/

Change-Id: Ibd951bf2a288bc1939495efda7e47778a2e96317

subject: Bump oslo.log for critical nova regression
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-02 17:57:01.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/6f08ccf8b93a85de9160f2ff9c7b5f7e7a267e38', 'message': 'Bump oslo.log for critical nova regression

Once Nova switched over to oslo.log, we realized that "instance"
objects were printed wrong in the nova logs. Essentially instead
of just the uuid, the entire __repr__ of the instance object was
printed in the logs, making them unreadable. This was fixed in
I2d1b09015bead2012327f973f45f3f6728160c69 and oslo.log 0.4.0
was released.

Related-Bug: #1426544
Change-Id: I982b165ed64494a14dcd6b2e78d3f43a3f75aa53
'}]
commit_message:
Bump oslo.log for critical nova regression

Once Nova switched over to oslo.log, we realized that "instance"
objects were printed wrong in the nova logs. Essentially instead
of just the uuid, the entire __repr__ of the instance object was
printed in the logs, making them unreadable. This was fixed in
I2d1b09015bead2012327f973f45f3f6728160c69 and oslo.log 0.4.0
was released.

Related-Bug: #1426544
Change-Id: I982b165ed64494a14dcd6b2e78d3f43a3f75aa53

commit_message:
Refactor and provide scaffolding for domain specific loading

In preparation for the support of loading domain specific
configuration options from a database backend, the existing
code structure for loading from files is refactored to make
this easier. In addition the config option to support
domain specific configurations loading from a database is
also added (which will result in a NotImplemented error if
it is enabled).

Partially Implements: blueprint domain-config-ext

Change-Id: Iaa7b11e3b719bd68635e7b8a5b7217993db41b1b

commit_message:
Tidy up clean-samples.yaml

Improve the readability and use of gabbi to be more in line with
what we've learned since this file was created. The primary changes
are:

* more liberal use of comments and white space for better
  readability
* JSON in the data section
* xfail with link to bugs when there are issues with the HTTP
  handling

The xfail in this case is that when a sample is POSTed there is no
location header in the response.

Change-Id: I6520ea133b3feb9a764b41ecf47bebcc33ca7cb4

commit_message:
Adding policy rest endpoint for angular

Providing an endpoint for angular code to make policy checks
on the horizon server. There currently is no clientside cache
of the calls, that will be a follow-on work.

Implements blueprint: policy-for-angular
Change-Id: Ieacbc502440c2e3a2e32ec6bcaa002310e82a681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/14/158914/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from django.views import generic from openstack_dashboard import policy from openstack_dashboard.api.rest import urls from openstack_dashboard.api.rest import utils as rest_utils @urls.register class Policy(generic.View): '''API for interacting with the policy engine.''' url_regex = r'policy/$' @rest_utils.ajax(data_required=True) def post(self, request): '''Check policy rules. Check the group of policy rules supplied in the POST application/json object. The policy target, if specified will also be passed in to the policy check method as well. The action returns the an object with one key: allowed and the value is the result of the policy check, True or False. ''' rules_in = request.DATA.get('rules') or [] rules = tuple([tuple(rule) for rule in rules_in]) policy_target = request.DATA.get('target') or {} if rules: result = policy.check(rules, request, policy_target) else: # no check being made, so success result = True return rest_utils.JSONResponse({"allowed": result})

commit_message:
Refactor of Metadata Widget

First step of making metadata widget logic reusable.

See dependent patches. It was hard to see the changes
in Gerrit when doing the renaming and refactoring at
once. Gerrit didn't seem to understand that it was
a rename, making the review more difficult to view.

Partial-Bug: 1394472
Change-Id: I01eac21bf78b4b5545405e1ae4cb9a11619e8bc6

commit_message:
Generate a drop down field for custom heat parameters

If the heat template parameter has a custom constraint of
'nova.flavor', 'nova.keypair', 'glance.image' or 'neutron.network',
the form will generate a drop down field with a list of all
possible options the current user has access to.

Change-Id: I17f99eca364f1123a950cf712225ce751728239e
blueprint: heat-template-choices
Co-Authored-By: Cdric Soulas <cedric.soulas@cloudwatt.com>

commit_message:
Add non-voting tempest dsvm job for Midonet

Add the non-voting tempest dsvm job for `networking-midonet` project,
which should run only for master branch. It is based in Kyle Mestery's
patch for `networking-odl`.

Change-Id: I922e37039c9f7fefd1238a7b9d6430e00f8ba126

commit_message:
Refactor Gerrit plugin build jobs

Make the Gerrit plugin job names a little more concise and make the
job a little more generic so that users can reuse it to build other
gerrit plugins.

Change-Id: Icfba74619b1dff65999882ad9f15d7c0fdb4c666

commit_message:
Limit target projects for the neutron func job

The neutron functional job does not rely on repositories other than
devstack and neutron, so limit the projects that devstack-gate updates
in the workspace accordingly.

This change also reverts the changes to the neutron api job that
validated that the functional job could safely run with a restricted
set of projects.

Change-Id: Ic59c3b2cc5d0b40a8f05c2d89eb1cf5e9e2f0d1d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/58/155958/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Limit manual jobs

Limit the jobs for the OpenStack manuals:
* Run checklinks only if xml files are changed.
* Run checksyntax only if xml, po, or pot files are changed.

Change-Id: Ic013476b704655455088b167e0e83e4d4db9fdee
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/06/158406/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: files: - '^.*\.xml$' - name: ^gate-.*-tox-checksyntax$ files: - '^.*\.po$' - '^.*\.pot$' - '^.*\.xml$'

commit_message:
Added the ml2_conf_ovs.ini file, cause its missing

This was found by Elliott, but I'm committing this.

This will also needed to back ported to stable/icehouse.

There are options in the attrubutes designed for local testing,
but the actual file/ovs setup isnt there. This adds it back.

Change-Id: I1a9ce717e0818b5ac41bc86c3279576e529b5419

commit_message:
Proposed Integration Testing conversation

This is the outline to start the discussion on how to create a
integration testing frame work.

Change-Id: If5d7e9bb6d38ad3cbe6065007552539c731e2104
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-chef-specs refs/changes/63/110763/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Integration Testing ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-chef/+spec/example Intro ===== This is the blueprint to layout the integration suite for the different chef cookbooks for Openstack. We have unit testing, but we need the next layer of testing to start seeing how the different cookbooks interact with one another. Problem description =================== * We need to have some integration testing so we can start gaining confidence in our cookbooks and have a way to catch regressions. Proposed change =============== Create the integration testing framework. Implementation ============== * Leverage `test-kitchen <http://kitchen.ci>`_ for the integration testing. * Create a ``.kitchen.yml`` for each cookbook that builds out a logical build for each cookbook. * Build and run this on a CI environment for just a logical grouping (roles). * Build and run this on a CI environment that builds out a complete Openstack cluster. Dependencies ============ * None, though this should be part of the work flow after we have it set up. Testing ======= * None, granted this *is* a testing framework. Documentation Impact ==================== * This will require an update to the work flow documentation. This should also be documented so other people/groups can create slave CI environments with this. References ========== * None.

commit_message:
Adding the Neutron Resource to client

This will add the neutron resource to the client cookbook

Change-Id: I2d5c05902497e38a4d4393a324c2658070cad35b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-client refs/changes/45/138845/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Cookbook Name:: openstack-client # Provider:: neutron-subnet # Author:: JJ Asghar # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # # Support why-run, this seems like a good idea def whyrun_supported? true end action :create do if @current_resource.exists Chef::Log.info "#{ @new_resource } already exists - nothing to do." else converge_by("Create #{ @new_resource }") do create_neutron_subnet end end end action :delete do if @current_resource.exists converge_by("Delete #{ @new_resource }") do delete_neutron_subnet end else Chef::Log.info "#{ @current_resource } doesn't exist - can't delete." end end def load_current_resource @current_resource = Chef::Resource::NeutronSubnet.new(@new_resource.name) @current_resource.name(@new_resource.name) @current_resource.allocation_pool_start(@new_resource.allocation_pool_start) @current_resource.allocation_pool_end(@new_resource.allocation_pool_end) @current_resource.disable_dhcp(@new_resource.disable_dhcp) @current_resource.gateway(@new_resource.gateway) @current_resource.subnet_cidr(@new_resource.subnet_cidr) if name_exists?(@current_resource.name) @current_resource.exists = true end end def create_neutron_subnet if :disable_dhcp = true bash "Creating neutron router #{ new_resource }" do code <<-EOH neutron subnet-create #{@new_resource.name} --name #{@new_resource.name} --allocation-pool start=#{@new_resource.allocation_pool_start},end=#{@new_resource.allocation_pool_end} --disable-dhcp --gateway #{@new_resource.gateway} #{@new_resource.subnet_cidr} EOH end else bash "Creating neutron router #{ new_resource }" do code <<-EOH neutron subnet-create #{@new_resource.name} --name #{@new_resource.name} --allocation-pool start=#{@new_resource.allocation_pool_start},end=#{@new_resource.allocation_pool_end} --gateway #{@new_resource.gateway} #{@new_resource.subnet_cidr} EOH end end end def delete_neutron_subnet bash "Deleting neutron subnet #{ new_resource }" do code <<-EOH neutron subnet-delete "#{ new_resource }" EOH end end

subject: Handle resize/migrate with config drivers on rbd
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-25 11:37:12.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5d087a159720510b8ed776bc047e5ed8ce73a0e4', 'message': 'Handle resize/migrate with config drivers on rbd

Since we store the config drive on rbd, the resize and migrate
of an instance should work, but the import of the config driver
is uncondionnal done even the config driver is already imported in
rbd.

This change fixes that by checking the existance of the config drive
before trying to re-upload it.

Related-bug: #1369627
Related-bug: #1361840
Fixes-bug: #1246201

Change-Id: I0da201f8719abbea20cf243ce38d012e80586096
'}]
commit_message:
Handle resize/migrate with config drivers on rbd

Since we store the config drive on rbd, the resize and migrate
of an instance should work, but the import of the config driver
is uncondionnal done even the config driver is already imported in
rbd.

This change fixes that by checking the existance of the config drive
before trying to re-upload it.

Related-bug: #1369627
Related-bug: #1361840
Fixes-bug: #1246201

Change-Id: I0da201f8719abbea20cf243ce38d012e80586096

commit_message:
Add Developer Guidelines docs page

Initially, this page contains guidance on the use of example
domain names and IP space throughout our codebase.

Change-Id: Id8b9aa6d924a43dbeedc5b9f3b858a4ff464fdf5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/74/160174/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ******************** Developer Guidelines ******************** Example DNS Names and IP Space ============================== The IANA has allocated several special purpose domains and IP blocks for use as examples in code and documentation. Where possible, these domains and IP blocks should be preferred. There are some cases where it will not be possible to follow this guidance, for example, there is currently no reserved IDN domain name. We prefer to use these names and IP blocks to avoid causing any unexpected collateral damage to the rightful owners of the non-reserved names and IP space. For example, publishing an email address in our codebase will more than likely be picked up by spammers, while published URLs etc using non-reserved names or IP space will likely trigger search indexers etc to begin crawling. Reserved Domains ---------------- Reserverd DNS domains are documented here: `IANA Special Use Domain Names`_. Several common reserved domains: * example.com. * example.net. * example.org. Reserved IP Space ----------------- Reserverd IP space is documented here: `IANA IPv4 Special Registry`_, and `IANA IPv6 Special Registry`_. Several common reserved IP blocks: * 192.0.2.0/24 * 198.51.100.0/24 * 203.0.113.0/24 * 2001:db8::/32 .. _IANA Special Use Domain Names: http://www.iana.org/assignments/special-use-domain-names/special-use-domain-names.xhtml .. _IANA IPv4 Special Registry: http://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv4-special-registry/iana-ipv4-special-registry.xhtml .. _IANA IPv6 Special Registry: http://www.iana.org/assignments/iana-ipv6-special-registry/iana-ipv6-special-registry.xhtml

commit_message:
Remove explicit thread-local update in context

oslo.context now handles this internally, so we can remove the
duplication. Additionally - This is the last explicit use of
oslo-incubator's local module, so we remove it and it's
reference in openstack-common.conf.

Change-Id: I649b1873f69a37c9acb5b13d6ae750782ed7776c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/14/160114/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # Copyright 2011 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Local storage of variables using weak references""" import threading import weakref class WeakLocal(threading.local): def __getattribute__(self, attr): rval = super(WeakLocal, self).__getattribute__(attr) if rval: # NOTE(mikal): this bit is confusing. What is stored is a weak # reference, not the value itself. We therefore need to lookup # the weak reference and return the inner value here. rval = rval() return rval def __setattr__(self, attr, value): value = weakref.ref(value) return super(WeakLocal, self).__setattr__(attr, value) # NOTE(mikal): the name "store" should be deprecated in the future store = WeakLocal() # A "weak" store uses weak references and allows an object to fall out of scope # when it falls out of scope in the code that uses the thread local storage. A # "strong" store will hold a reference to the object so that it never falls out # of scope. weak_store = WeakLocal() strong_store = threading.local()

commit_message:
Explicitly add noproxy for congress host for curl

Curl seems to have issue with no_proxy for sub net, e.g.
10.2.2.1/16. So explicitly specifying noproxy for congress
host could avoid this kind of issue.

Change-Id: Ic957ff7ab5cd2f6d383ab56c2b165589b2d9fad1

commit_message:
Get initiator from manager and send to controller

Using the WSGI context that is available at the manager layer,
we can get the Initiator content we need and forward it to the manager
classes.

Co-Authored-By: Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
partially implements bp: cadf-everywhere

Change-Id: I6b7885d29cd733c5040bea6003dd93607cb5821e

commit_message:
Implement encryption proxy middleware for server-side-encryption.

Design information on
  https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Swift/server-side-enc

Uses a static key manager and PyCrypto. Encryption with AES in
various chaning modes including CBC mode. The encryption format will
permit range reads.

Change-Id: I734f22ca8cf29b33eaaeebf581c146f0a73a38ea
Implements: blueprint swift-enc-proxy
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/73/122773/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2010-2012 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """ Encryption for objects The ``encryption`` middleware provides server-side encryption for the objects stored in Swift. Encryption is enabled on a container level, i.e. all objects in a container will be encrypted if the encryption is enabled for the container upon its creation. This is done by adding a "X-Container-Meta-Encrypt-Enabled" header with value "On". Also, the user may specify a default encryption algorithm for the container at creation time, with the header "X-Container-Meta-Encrypt-Algorithm"; if none is provided, the container encryption algorithm is set according to the configuration settings. Currently, all objects within a container will be encrypted with the default encryption algorithm, though a per-object algorithm support can trivially be added at later time if needed. Each object is encrypted with a per-object key and IV. The object key is wrapped with a container key and stored in the object system metadata of the object, together with other object-specific values. Keys are organised in a hierarchy and delegated to the key manager component from ``KeyHierarchy.`` The current default implementation uses the "direct" key hierarchy that is strictly hierarchical, starting from a master key that protects account keys, which in turn protect container keys, which in turn protect object keys. The chosen key hierarchy can be set through a configuration option. The master keys are managed by a ``KeyManager,`` which can be set as a configuration option. One such key manager is based on Barbican, which will be the preferred choice as it is an Openstack project (TODO -- this is not yet implemented). The key manager only supports wrapping and unwrapping of an account key when given an authentikation token. The ``encryption`` middleware uses an abstract ``CryptoInterface`` as a provider of the required cryptographic operations. These include key generation, encryption, decryption, and context creation and serialization. There are several options for implementing the crypto library, e.g., PyCrypto, M2Crypto, and others. Currently PyCrypto is the only supported crypto provider, and it is a prerequisite for this code. See also: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Swift/server-side-enc """ import sys from hashlib import md5 from swift.common.request_helpers import get_sys_meta_prefix, \ get_user_meta_prefix from swift.common.swob import wsgify, Request, HTTPServerError from swift.common.utils import (config_true_value, split_path, get_logger) # swiftenc from enclib.key_manager_base import KeyManager from enclib.crypto_base import CryptoInterface, CryptoInterfaceError from enclib.key_hierarchy_base import KeyHierarchy, derive_path class SwiftEnc(object): """ Encryption Middleware Add encryption to the pipeline in proxy-server.conf by including: swiftenc near the end, but before proxy-logging, in the entry: pipeline = and specify additionally: [filter:swiftenc] use = egg:swift#encryption crypto_interface = \ swift.common.middleware.enclib.crypto_py:CryptoPY key_manager = \ swift.common.middleware.enclib.key_manager_static:StaticKeyManager hierarchy_implementation = \ swift.common.middleware.enclib.key_hierarchy_direct:DirectHierarchy default_enc_alg = aes_128_cbc default_wrap_alg = aes_128_cbc slice_size = 4194304 :param app: The next WSGI app in the pipeline :param conf: The dict of configuration values """ def __init__(self, app, conf): self.app = app self.logger = get_logger(conf, log_route="encryption") crypto = conf.get("crypto_interface", "missing-conf-crypto") self.crypto = instantiate_derived_class(CryptoInterface, crypto, conf) mkm = conf.get("key_manager", "missing-conf-mkm") self.mkm = instantiate_derived_class(KeyManager, mkm, conf, self.crypto) hrchy = conf.get("hierarchy_implementation", "missing-conf-hrchy") self.hrchy = instantiate_derived_class(KeyHierarchy, hrchy, conf, self.crypto, self.mkm) self.default_enc_alg = conf.get("default_enc_algorithm", "aes_128_cbc") self.slice_size = conf.get("slice_size", "4194304") assert (self.slice_size >= 1024), "Slice size must be at least 1024." self.CONT_USER_ENCRYPT = (get_user_meta_prefix('container') + 'encryption-enabled') self.CONT_USER_ALG = (get_user_meta_prefix('container') + 'encryption-algorithm') self.CONT_ENCRYPT = get_sys_meta_prefix('container') + 'enc-enabled' self.CONT_ALG = get_sys_meta_prefix('container') + 'enc-algorithm' self.OBJ_PLAIN_ETAG = get_sys_meta_prefix('object') + 'enc-etag' self.OBJ_PLAIN_LENGTH = get_sys_meta_prefix('object') + 'enc-length' self.OBJ_ENC_PLAIN_SLICE = (get_sys_meta_prefix('object') + 'enc-plain-slice-size') self.OBJ_ENC_CIPHER_SLICE = (get_sys_meta_prefix('object') + 'enc-cipher-slice-size') def __call__(self, env, start_response): """ Accept a standard WSGI call and proceed according the request. For a container, if PUT and encryption is enabled, we need to initiliaze the container key and set the appropraite system metadata if a first PUT for the given container (response w/ 201). Otherwise, we set the header values inidicating whether the container is encrypted based on sysmeta. Object requests are handled according to type: PUT: if the container has encryption enabled, create an object key and proceed accordingly; the wrapped key and encryption context are stored as object system metadata together with the plaintext tag (de-etag) and size (de-etag). The wrapped key header entry depends on the container name as described on the wiki page. GET: if the object is encrypted, decrypt and check the encryption tag(s) POST: noting if obj-systmeta is implemented; otherwise, preserve the encryption object headers HEAD: replace en-etag and en-size with de-etag and de-size in the response headers COPY: get the object key rewrapped with the target container key and POST it; then do a regular COPY. """ self.hrchy.init_cache(env) req = Request(env) path_ver, path_acc, path_cont, path_obj = \ split_path(req.path, 1, 4, False) # container if path_acc and path_cont and not path_obj: if req.method == "PUT": return self.app_cont_init(env, start_response) else: return self.app_cont_resp(env, start_response) # object if path_acc and path_cont and path_obj: if req.method == "GET": return self.app_obj_decrypt(env, start_response) elif req.method == "PUT": return self.app_obj_encrypt(env, start_response) elif req.method == "COPY": return self.app_obj_copy(env, start_response) return self.app_obj_resp(env, start_response) # anything else return self.app(env, start_response) @wsgify def app_cont_init(self, req): """ Initialize a container. If this is the first PUT for the container then set the "cont-sys-enc" and "cont-sys-alg" system metadata values based on the headers set by the user. """ encryption_header = self.CONT_USER_ENCRYPT if config_true_value(req.headers.get(encryption_header)): req.headers[encryption_header] = "" resp = req.get_response(self.app) if resp.status_int == 201: enc_alg = req.headers.get(self.CONT_USER_ALG, self.default_enc_alg) headers = self.hrchy.init_container( req.headers["X-Auth-Token"], self.app, req.path) headers.update({ self.CONT_ENCRYPT: "on", self.CONT_ALG: enc_alg }) self._post_headers(self.app, req.path, headers) return resp else: return req.get_response(self.app) @wsgify def app_cont_resp(self, req): """ Set the "cont-meta-enc" and "cont-meta-alg" header values in the response based on the corresponding system metadata headers. """ resp = req.get_response(self.app) for header in resp.headers.keys(): if header.lower() == self.CONT_ENCRYPT: resp.headers[self.CONT_USER_ENCRYPT] = "On" if header.lower() == self.CONT_ALG: resp.headers[self.CONT_USER_ALG] \ = resp.headers.get(self.CONT_ALG) return resp @wsgify def app_obj_resp(self, req): """ Default response for object requests which are not PUT, GET, COPY """ # TODO -- preserve object sysmeta headers for POST resp = req.get_response(self.app) # TODO -- update response headers return resp @wsgify def app_obj_encrypt(self, req): """ Encrypt object during PUT. These metadata entries are set for each object: "obj-sys-enc-key": the wrapped object key "obj-sys-enc-context": the encryption context for the object, e.g. IV and enc. algorithm "obj-sys-de-etag": the etag before the object is encrypted "obj-sys-de-size": the object size before encryption TODO -- there are more """ # TODO -- consider that self.slice_size is not a multiple of blocksize enc_alg = self.get_cont_enc_alg(req.path) if enc_alg: obj_key, obj_context \ = self.hrchy.create_obj_key(req, self.app, enc_alg) # TODO -- avoid another pass over body here to compute etag plain_etag = md5(req.body).hexdigest() plain_length = req.headers["Content-Length"] req.headers.update({ self.OBJ_PLAIN_ETAG: plain_etag, self.OBJ_PLAIN_LENGTH: plain_length, self.OBJ_ENC_PLAIN_SLICE: self.slice_size }) # A slice is the unit of encryption and decryption; an # encrypted slice is generally longer than its plaintext # equivalent due to the padding. All slices are of the # same length OBJ_ENC_PLAIN_SLICE, except for the last # one, which may be shorter. Every plaintext slice is # transformed to a ciphertext slice. Ciphertext slices, # again, are of the same length OBJ_ENC_CIPHER_SLICE # except for the last one, which may be shorter. The # lengths are determined from the padding method used # during encryption, possibly also from authenticated # encryption. When the header OBJ_ENC_CIPHER_SLICE value # is equal to or larger than the ``Content-Length:`` # header, then the ciphertext consists of a single slice. cipher_slice_size = 0 plain_data = req.body try: # position of next by to encrypt in plaintext plain_pos = 0 cipher_data = '' while plain_pos < len(plain_data): next_pos = plain_pos + int(self.slice_size) if next_pos < len(plain_data): cipher_slice = self.crypto.encrypt( obj_key, plain_data[plain_pos:next_pos], obj_context, plain_pos ) if cipher_slice_size == 0: cipher_slice_size = len(cipher_slice) elif cipher_slice_size != len(cipher_slice): raise HTTPServerError('Object encryption failed ' 'due to slice size glitch') else: next_pos = len(plain_data) cipher_slice = self.crypto.encrypt( obj_key, plain_data[plain_pos:next_pos], obj_context, plain_pos ) cipher_data += cipher_slice plain_pos = next_pos if cipher_slice_size == 0: cipher_slice_size = len(cipher_data) req.body = cipher_data except CryptoInterfaceError as ce: self.logger.exception('Error in app_obj_encrypt: ' + ce.msg) raise HTTPServerError('Object encryption failed', request=req) req.headers.update({ self.OBJ_ENC_CIPHER_SLICE: cipher_slice_size # TODO -- why not set Content-Length here? # "Content-Length": len(req.body) }) if int(req.headers["Content-Length"]) != len(req.body): raise HTTPServerError('Object encryption failed, ' + 'lengths of ciphertext do not match') return req.get_response(self.app) def get_cont_enc_alg(self, path): """ Check whether a container has encryption enabled and return the encryption algorithm if so. """ cont_path = derive_path(path, 3) cont_headers = self._get_headers(self.app, cont_path) if self.CONT_ENCRYPT in cont_headers.keys(): return cont_headers.get(self.CONT_ALG, self.default_enc_alg) else: return None @wsgify def app_obj_copy(self, req): """ Duplicate an encrypted object during COPY. """ # TODO raise NotImplementedError("No COPY operation for encrypted objects.") def app_obj_decrypt(self, env, start_response): """ Decrypt an object during GET. Decrypt an object, check the validty tags, and adjust the response headers with the system metadata values set during the PUT. """ req = Request(env) decrypt_ok = [] cipher_context = {} # TODO -- patch headers to req.headers.update({"Range": "bytes=x-y"}) if req.range: raise NotImplementedError( "No support of ranges for encrypted objects.") def start_decrypt(status, resp_headers, exc_info=None): headers = dict(map(lambda(k, v): (k.lower(), v), resp_headers)) cipher_context.clear() length = headers.get('content-length') if length is not None: cipher_context["content-length"] = length slice_size = headers.get(self.OBJ_ENC_CIPHER_SLICE) if slice_size is not None: cipher_context["cipher-slice-size"] = slice_size # recognize an encrypted object from its OBJ_PLAIN_ETAG del decrypt_ok[:] if self.OBJ_PLAIN_ETAG in headers: decrypt_ok.append(True) obj_key, obj_context = \ self.hrchy.get_obj_key(req.headers["X-Auth-Token"], self.app, req.path, headers) cipher_context["key"] = obj_key cipher_context["iv"] = obj_context.get("iv") cipher_context["alg"] = obj_context.get("alg") cipher_context["tag"] = obj_context.get("tag") cipher_context["blocksize"] = obj_context.get("blocksize") resp_headers = self.adjust_resp_obj_headers(resp_headers) write = start_response(status, resp_headers, exc_info) if decrypt_ok: def write_decrypt(data): # TODO -- why is this is here? write(self.crypto.decrypt(cipher_context["key"], data, cipher_context, False)) return write_decrypt else: return write return DecryptIter(self.app(env, start_decrypt), self.crypto, cipher_context, decrypt_ok) def adjust_resp_obj_headers(self, headers): plain_etag = self.OBJ_PLAIN_ETAG.lower() plain_length = self.OBJ_PLAIN_LENGTH.lower() adj_headers = filter(lambda (n, v): n.lower() not in ["content-length", "etag"], headers) def patch_headers((n, v)): nn = n.lower() if nn == plain_etag: return ("Etag", v) elif nn == plain_length: return ("Content-Length", v) else: return (n, v) return map(patch_headers, adj_headers) def _post_headers(self, app, path, headers): new_env = {"PATH_INFO": path, "REQUEST_METHOD": "POST"} new_req = Request.blank(path, environ=new_env, headers=headers) resp = new_req.get_response(app) if not resp.is_success: raise HTTPServerError("Unable to update headers with metadata" " for encryption or decryption") def _get_headers(self, app, path): new_env = {"CONTENT_LENGTH": 0, "REQUEST_METHOD": "HEAD"} new_req = Request.blank(path, environ=new_env) resp = new_req.get_response(app) if not resp.is_success: raise HTTPServerError("Unable to retrieve metadata from headers" " for encryption or decryption") return dict((k.lower(), v) for (k, v) in resp.headers.iteritems()) class DecryptIter(object): """ Return an iterable that yields the decrypted HTTP response body for use during decryption operations. """ def __init__(self, result, crypto, cipher_context, decrypt_ok): if hasattr(result, "close"): self.close = result.close self._next = iter(result).next self.crypto = crypto self.cipher_context = cipher_context self.decrypt_ok = decrypt_ok self.cipher_obj = None self.cipher_slice_size = 0 # position of next decrypted byte in already decrypted plaintext self.plain_absolute_pos = 0 # position of next byte to decrypt in ciphertext self.cipher_absolute_pos = 0 # position of next byte to decrypt in slice of ciphertext self.cipher_slice_pos = 0 def __iter__(self): return self def next(self): cipher_data = self._next() if not self.decrypt_ok: return cipher_data if self.cipher_slice_size == 0: self.cipher_slice_size = int(self.cipher_context[ "cipher-slice-size"]) self.cipher_len = int(self.cipher_context["content-length"]) # cipher_data may be located anywhere in a slice plain_data = '' cipher_pos = 0 while cipher_pos < len(cipher_data): if self.cipher_slice_pos == 0: self.cipher_obj = \ self.crypto.decrypt_init(self.cipher_context["key"], self.cipher_context, self.plain_absolute_pos) if cipher_pos - self.cipher_slice_pos + self.cipher_slice_size \ < len(cipher_data): # decrypt until the end of the slice, the slice ends next_pos = (cipher_pos - self.cipher_slice_pos + self.cipher_slice_size) else: # decrypt until the end of cipher_data, slice may end or not next_pos = len(cipher_data) progress = next_pos - cipher_pos if progress <= 0: raise HTTPServerError('Object decryption failed, ' 'nothing to decrypt') if (self.cipher_slice_pos + progress < self.cipher_slice_size) \ and (self.cipher_absolute_pos + progress < self.cipher_len): plain_chunk = self.crypto.decrypt_update( cipher_data[cipher_pos:next_pos], self.cipher_context, self.cipher_obj) self.cipher_slice_pos += progress else: plain_chunk = self.crypto.decrypt_finalize( cipher_data[cipher_pos:next_pos], self.cipher_context, self.cipher_obj) self.cipher_slice_pos = 0 cipher_pos = next_pos plain_data += plain_chunk self.cipher_absolute_pos += progress self.plain_absolute_pos += len(plain_chunk) return plain_data def instantiate_derived_class(base_class, config_entry, *args, **kwargs): """ Instantiate a base class with a derived class specified in the configuration with the provided parameters. """ try: derived_module, derived_class = config_entry.split(":") __import__(derived_module) derived_class = getattr(sys.modules[derived_module], derived_class) if issubclass(derived_class, base_class): return derived_class(*args, **kwargs) else: raise ValueError() except (ImportError, AttributeError, ValueError): raise ImportError("Cannot derive %s from base class %s" % (config_entry, base_class.__name__)) def filter_factory(global_conf, **local_conf): conf = global_conf.copy() conf.update(local_conf) def swiftenc_filter(app): return SwiftEnc(app, conf) return swiftenc_filter

commit_message:
Add in non-decorator notifiers

Add non-decorator based notifiers in. These notifiers will be used
in lieu of the decorator based notifiers so that the initiator can
be passed through to the manager for notification that does not
result in suboptimal design patterns where an argument is passed to
the manager for the sole purpose of the decorator inspecting for it
to populate data in the CADF notifications.

partially implements bp: cadf-everywhere

Change-Id: I684cf11325ffa7e6320088bd8b8ebb6cda29ad12

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Cleanup in TestHyperVUtilsV2

Refactors a part of the tests, specifically the
parts related to patching the method
'_get_switch_port_allocation', which can be
done in a simpler, cleaner way.

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Skips already performed actions

Adds a check in order to avoid reconnecting vswitch
ports if they are already connected.

Adds a check in order to avoid readding the VLAN
setting data if it already exists and is properly set.

Closes-Bug: #1422439

Change-Id: I3ae4d7de419a52470789d54f2dacea1f38f3a599

commit_message:
Removes unused argument from disconnect_switch_port

The method 'disconnect_switch_port' in the classes
HyperVUtils and HyperVUtilsV2 does not use the given
'vswitch_name' argument, so there is no point in
having it at all.

Change-Id: I8d02be172e3951e1eefc2354c819a47fbbf3928c

commit_message:
Add requirement for APIImpact flag

Adds a requirement for an APIImpact flag in
the commit message for a proposed spec if it proposes
changes to the Swift REST API. This will make it
much easier for people such as the API WG who want to
review API changes across OpenStack to find and
review proposed API changes.

Change-Id: I3cadb5e26423a5c493ac2d98b84760980dc24183
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/42/132342/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: If your specification proposes any changes to the Swift REST API such as changing parameters which can be returned or accepted, or even the semantics of what happens when a client calls into the API, then you should add the APIImpact flag to the commit message. Specifications with the APIImpact flag can be found with the following query: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/swift-specs+message:apiimpact,n,z

commit_message:
Adds Hyper-V Agent configurations getter

Adds a method that returns configurations that will be used by
the Hyper-V ML2 Mechanism Driver and other neutron services.
Those configurations will be set in the agent state.

Change-Id: I5ebc6fc7b5f322a0ef5d4b06cd69333cfef89762
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-hyperv refs/changes/51/159151/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_agent_configurations(self): """Returns agent configurations to be used by neutron and the Hyper-V ML2 Mechanism Driver.""" configurations = {'vswitch_mappings': self._physical_network_mappings} return configurations

subject: Draft specification for storage encryption in Swift

commit_message:
Draft specification for storage encryption in Swift

This draft serves for agreeing on the security goals of encryption
support in Swift, its design and important implementation choices.

This spec is based on the "spec for on-disk encryption" here
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/123220/
and extends the security model and the design. It also takes
into account some of the discussion there.

For relevant background, see also the earlier blueprint
  https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/swift-enc-proxy

Change-Id: Ib683db83252e649328e7d4790e87524430132db8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift-specs refs/changes/80/126880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ****************** Storage Encryption ****************** 1. Goals ======== To better protect the data in their clusters, Swift clients and operators may wish to have objects stored in an encrypted form. This spec describes a plan to add an encryption capability to Swift. Storage encryption for Swift is concerned with encrypting objects on the proxy server. It addresses a broader scope than disk-level encryption, where data is encrypted by the disk or near the disk interface. The present encryption design protects objects at a higher level and against a broader set of attacks than disk encryption. The storage encryption design allows to use different keys and key managers depending on the account and owner of objects, especially for supporting clusters that serve to multiple non-trusting clients. 2. Security Model ================= Swift objects are processed by stateless proxy servers, stored on object servers, and travel over a network between them. Metadata is stored on further servers. This spec describes a way to minimize the information leaked when an attacker can get access to a Swift cluster or parts of it. Encryption is performed in the proxy server; the internal network and the object servers only get to see protected data. In the object servers, Swift objects are typically stored on disk as files in a standard POSIX filesystem; in the typical 3-replica case, an object is represented as 3 files on 3 distinct filesystems on 3 servers within the cluster. An attacker may gain access to object data in a number of ways. By storage layer, from bottom up, objects are exposed 1. on disk; 2. in the object server; 3. in the cluster network; 4. in the proxy server. **Exposure on disk** When a disk fails, it may be returned to the manufacturer under warranty; since it has failed, erasing the data may not be possible, but the data may still be present on the platters. When disks reach end-of-life, they are discarded, and if not properly wiped, may still contain data. An attacker may simply break into the data center and steal disks. **Attack on object server** An attacker may get user-level or root access to an object server, where it may read objects from the file system, or even modify them, or even modify the server process. **Attack on cluster network** An attacker may be snooping on the cluster traffic between proxies and object servers; in a more severe attack it may also inject network traffic and forge requests to servers. **Attack on the proxy server** An attacker may get access to a proxy server, inspect its configuration and its memory, modify its behavior, and send forged requests to other services. This design protects objects from being leaked due to attacks on the disks, on the object servers, and on the cluster. It does not protect objects from attack on the proxy servers, and it does not protect against data loss caused by attackers. For protection against exposure on disk alone, storage encryption on the proxy server would be overkill. If the goal of encryption in Swift were limited to this, then that goal could be achieved with easier with file-system encryption or with device encryption on the object servers (for example, ecryptfs or dm-crypt/LUKS on Linux). Not The Threat Model -------------------- There are other ways to attack a Swift cluster, but this spec does not address them. In particular, this spec does not address these threats: * an attacker that gains access to Swift's internal network to cause data loss * an attacker gains access to the proxy nodes or other services such as authentication servers or key managers * an attacker modifies Swift's code If these threats are mitigated at all, it is a fortunate byproduct, but it is not the intent of this spec to address them. 3. Encryption and Key Management ================================ There are two logical parts to data encryption on the proxy server. The first part is the crypto engine; this performs the actual encryption and decryption of the data and metadata, and it also takes care of any necessary data integrity (a.k.a. authentication) functions. The second part is the keymaster. This is the part responsible for retrieving the secret key for the requested object. The crypto engine and the keymaster shall be implemented as three separate pieces of middleware. The crypto engine shall have both "decrypter" and "encrypter" filter-factory functions, and the "keymaster" filter shall sit between them. Example:: [pipeline:main] pipeline = catch_errors gatekeeper ... decrypter keymaster encrypter proxy-logging proxy-server A configuration that has only one of encrypter and decrypter present is not permitted. The encrypter middleware is responsible for encrypting and authenticating the object's data and metadata on a PUT or POST request. The decrypter middleware is responsible for decrypting and verifying the authenticity of the object's data and metadata on a GET or HEAD response. Depending on the implementation of key management, DELETE and OPTIONS requests may need to clean up keys or report information. Otherwise, they should be unaffected by encryption and authentication. The decrypter, encrypter, and keymaster will all use the hook in the WSGI environment at "swift.copy_hook" to ensure that COPY requests result in the new object being encrypted with its own key, not with the source object's key. An object will be encrypted with its own key that is not used anywhere else and stored in the object's sysmeta, wrapped with the actual key provided by the keymaster. This permits efficent implementation of COPY and re-key operations. Inter-Middleware Communication ------------------------------ The keymaster communicates the encryption key to the encrypter and decrypter middlewares by placing it in the WSGI environment dictionary at the name "swift.crypto.key". On a PUT or POST request, the keymaster must place the key in the WSGI environment during request processing; that is, before passing the request to the remainder of the middleware pipeline. This is so that the encrypter can encrypt the object's data in a streaming fashion without buffering the whole object. On a GET or HEAD request, the keymaster must place the key in the WSGI environment before returning control to the decrypter. It need not be done at request-handling time. This lets attributes of the key be stored in sysmeta, for example the key ID in an external database. 4. Cryptography =============== 4.1. Security Goals ------------------- The data encryption function must protect confidentiality and may additionally protect authenticity. By using an authenticated encryption mode, for example, both goals can be satisfied by one algorithm. 4.2. Cryptographic Architecture ------------------------------- The crypto engine may use a selected number of symmetric encryption algorithms for object encryption. The cryptographic algorithm can be selected by the operator from a set of choices hard-coded in the software. The code architecture should permit to extend this set of algorithms in a simple way, in response to security and possibly other issues unknown at this time. However, no direct access to the cryptographic algorithm configuration is permitted to the operator. Choosing an encryption algorithm and mode requires a good, up-to-date understanding of cryptography; choosing the wrong encryption mode has dire consequences. The supported and hard-coded algorithms should be reviewed broadly and be generally accepted by the relevant security guidelines. The encrypter, decrypter, and keymaster middlewares rely on a crypto library for implementations of their cryptographic algorithms. Details of this crypto library should be abstracted, so as to permit the replacement of the library in the future, should the current implementation pose some issues. PyCrypto appears to be the most suitable crypto library currently available in Python. 4.3. Cryptographic Algorithms ----------------------------- Only cryptographic algorithms that are widely respected to be secure shall be provided. For accommodating the needs different environments, regulations, and native support for encryption modes, different algorithms may be available. AES256-GCM (AES Galois/Counter Mode, according to NIST SP800-38D) shall be supported for encryption and for authenticated encryption. It should be set as the default mode. AES256-CBC with HMAC-SHA256 (AES Cipher-Block Chaining Mode with HMAC using SHA256, according to NIST SP 800-38A) shall be supported. Further authenticated encryption algorithms according to IEEE P1619.1 (Authenticated Encryption with Length Expansion for Storage Devices) may be supported in the future. 4.4. Justification of Cryptographic Algorithm --------------------------------------------- While it may seem reasonable to use a scheme based on MD5, such as HMAC-MD5, given that the encrypter will already have to compute the MD5 hash of the uploaded object (to check the client-supplied etag, if given), the way HMAC is constructed does not allow the encrypter to reuse that work. From a security standpoint MD5 has to be considered broken today. For avoiding complications when reading or updating only a sub-range of an object, it may be tempting to use Counter Mode (CTR) or a stream cipher. CTR mode basically turns a block cipher into a stream cipher, so dealing with range GET requests becomes much easier. No modification of the byte ranges is required. When decrypting, some padding will be required to align the requested data to AES's 16-byte block size, but that can all be done at the proxy level. However, this works only when no authentication is needed, as one needs to pick a scope for the authentication tag. If there is one tag for the whole object, one can not decrypt and authenticate a range smaller than the whole object. (Think of streaming a video and the signal from the authentication check whether the stream was authentic arrives only after 2h. The damage may already have been done.) Hence one must introduce another unit, which governs the span of authenticated encryption; each such unit has a tag. This unit is called a slice. Its use is explained under "Encryption Format." 4.5. Encryption Format ---------------------- When using AES or any other block cipher, an object is encrypted in 16-byte "blocks". This needs some padding for 16-byte alignment, but that's simple. However multiple blocks need to be bound together so that their ciphertexts depend on each other, otherwise information leaks. Stream ciphers or CTR mode would not require such binding but cannot provide data authentication. Hence a unit of encryption is used called a "slice." Encryption is done on the object in a sequence of slices. Every slice has the same length (except for the last slice), which may be a configuration option for the operator. A plaintext slice is transformed into a ciphertext slice that may be longer than the plaintext slice. Again every ciphertext slice except for the last one has the same length. According to the choice of encryption algorithm, especially in an authenticated encryption mode, the ciphertext slice may contain the authentication tag for the slice. Ranged GETs have to be projected into a range of slices that covers the desired range. The slice size is stored as sysmeta of the object, which permits the decryptor to derive the correct slice for starting decryption and authenticity verification. Once every slice is properly decrypted and authenticated, the desired plaintext range is extracted and sent back to the client. During decryption with an authenticated mode, no plaintext should be returned to the client unless the authentication has been verified and passed. The choice of slice length is a complex security-performance tradeoff: a longer slice means we learn later that data has been tampered with, and we waste more work decrypting sub-ranges, but we have less overhead. A good default slice length would be similar to the default chunk length in Swift (but it must not be the same, as chunk length is more dynamic). As a consequence, the size of an encrypted object at the object server may differ from the size of the object visible to the user. 5. Robustness ============= 5.1 Wrong Key ------------- If the keymaster hands back a different key for decryption than was used for encryption, the client will receive garbage. To prevent this, the encrypter will add a sysmeta entry together with the wrapped object key and iv. For example one can use authenticated encryption for the plaintext-etag. If this fails to decrypt under the given object key, the key is wrong or the encrypted etag-data has been tampered with. This allows fail-safe operation. Note that, in principle, with authenticated encryption one also learns whether the key is "correct" during decryption, but only at a later stage, when there is already data being piped through. But this may be too late and it does not work when no authentication is used. 5.2 No Key ---------- If the keymaster fails to add a key to the WSGI environment, then the client will receive the ciphertext of the object instead of the plaintext, which looks to the client like garbage. However, we can tell if an object is encrypted or not by the presence of system metadata headers (e.g. the MD5 hash of the encryption key), so the decrypter can prevent this by raising an error if no key was provided for the decryption of an encrypted object. 6. Multiple Keymasters ====================== 6.1 Coexisting Keymasters ------------------------- Just as Swift supports multiple simultaneous auth systems, it can support multiple simultaneous keymasters. With auth, each auth system claims a subset of the Swift namespace by looking at accounts starting with their reseller prefix. Similarly, multiple keymasters may partition the Swift namespace in some way and thus coexist peacefully. 6.2 Keymasters in Core Swift ---------------------------- 6.2.1 Trivial Keymaster ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Swift will need a trivial keymaster for functional tests of the crypto engine. The trivial keymaster will not be suitable for production use at all. To that end, it should be deliberately kept as small as possible without regard for any actual security of the keys. I propose the idea that the trivial keymaster use the SHA-256 of a configurable prefix concatenated with the object's full path for the cryptographic key. That is,:: key = SHA256(prefix_from_conf + request.path) This will allow for testing of the PUT and GET paths, the COPY path (the destination object's key will differ from the source object's), and also the invalid key path (by changing the prefix after an object is PUT). 6.2.2 Barbican Keymaster ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Swift should also use a keymaster that is aligned with BarbicanKeyManager, as used by Cinder or by Nova. 7. Metadata Encryption ====================== 7.1 User Metadata ----------------- Not just the contents of an object are sensitive; metadata is sensitive too. User metadata will be encrypted with the same key and IV as the rest of the metadata. Since metadata values must be valid UTF-8 strings, the encrypted values will be Base64-encoded for storage. Also, the object's plaintext etag is obviously sensitive information and will be stored encrypted as well. Note that the actual metadata field "Etag" will contain the MD5 hash of the ciphertext so that the object server will not error out on an object PUT, and also so that the object auditor will not quarantine the object due to hash mismatch. The encrypted field is the sysmeta field where the MD5 of the plaintext is ultimately stored. Careful selection of counter values for etag encryption will be required. Re-use of a counter for two different metadata items will make metadata trivially decryptable by any attacker who understands how XOR works. 7.2 System Metadata ------------------- See "Open Questions" section at the end of this document. 7.3 Container Listings ====================== The etag in the container listings will be the MD5 of the ciphertext, while the etag on a GET or HEAD request will be the MD5 of the plaintext. It is not possible to make the etag match up everywhere. The etag is stored in three locations: * object metadata, "Etag" field: MD5 of ciphertext * object metadata, some sysmeta field: MD5 of plaintext * container listing: ??? Since the MD5 of the plaintext is sensitive enough to be stored encrypted, it seems foolish to then store it in the clear in the container database. Note that this *will not* break static large objects (SLO), since it relies on object HEAD requests for manifest validation, and then it checks etags against the headers on GET responses. Also, this *will not* break dynamic large objects (DLO), since DLOs don't check etags at all. 8. Open Questions ================= The questions here should be resolved prior to accepting this spec. 8.1 Sysmeta Encryption ====================== Should sysmeta be encrypted as well? Some sysmeta values can be sensitive, but if middleware is moved from pre-crypto to post-crypto or vice versa, all its existing sysmeta may become unusable garbage from its viewpoint. 8.2 Use of Authenticated Encryption =================================== Should authenticated encryption be used? Use of an authenticated encryption mode is desirable from a security standpoint. It does introduce some overhead and reduces performance more than non-authenticated encryption, however it implies changes to the encryption format and code design that should be addressed now. 8.3 Configurability of Encryption Algorithms ============================================ How much control should the operator have in selecting encryption algorithms and parameters? 8.4 Selective Encryption Controlled by User =========================================== Assuming a Swift instance provides encryption, should the user be allowed to select encryption? If yes, at which level? (Account, Container, Object?) As the user has this choice with other object stores, it would be good to allow this, at least on the granularity of containers.

subject: Don't call schedule_routers for a remove_router_interface
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-26 22:07:54.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/api/rpc/agentnotifiers/l3_rpc_agent_api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e86cb878c4c47146c2a071b0c0ced383f5cb9e08', 'message': "Don't call schedule_routers for a remove_router_interface

Calling schedule_routers when doing a remove_router_interface
can cause significant performance problems in scaled environments.
This is due to check_ports_exist_on_l3agent unnecessarily looping
through large numbers of ports for every l3 agent.

Change-Id: I64f23e344c72ba78a617bb5f682d2e2bfeceac55
Closes-Bug: #1420032
"}]
commit_message:
Don't call schedule_routers for a remove_router_interface

Calling schedule_routers when doing a remove_router_interface
can cause significant performance problems in scaled environments.
This is due to check_ports_exist_on_l3agent unnecessarily looping
through large numbers of ports for every l3 agent.

Change-Id: I64f23e344c72ba78a617bb5f682d2e2bfeceac55
Closes-Bug: #1420032
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/159623/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if operation != 'remove_router_interface': plugin.schedule_routers(adminContext, router_ids)
deleted_lines: plugin.schedule_routers(adminContext, router_ids)

subject: Clear migration_status from a destination volume if migration fails
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-11 02:14:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/728b8692a12e9dbe445d7ec968b71d097695c9c9', 'message': "Clear migration_status from a destination volume if migration fails

When some error happens during volume migration, cinder-volume
keeps remaining destination volume because the volume copy may be
in the completing phase and the source volume may be deleted already.

However the migration_status of destination volume in DB is not
updated during error handling, the volume can't be deleted even if
it is unnecessary volume.

This change adds DB update process to clear migration_status flag
during error handling of migrate volume.

Closes-Bug: #1403916
Change-Id: Ie4199bc1e804e5cbbb793f448a99487f9823f1a9
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-02-13 20:21:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a568147adbe9fd0ba68d37ed06b7db68a63eaa14', 'message': "Clear migration_status from a destination volume if migration fails

When some error happens during volume migration, cinder-volume
keeps remaining a destination volume because the volume copy may be
in the completing phase and a source volume may be deleted already.

In this case, the migration_status of the destination volume in
data base should be cleared. As a result, the volume can be handled
properly even if volume migration is failed. If the migration is
in the migrating phase, the volume should be deleted and an entry
of database is also destroyed because the source volume is remaining.

Also there is an another problem that a source volume is remaining
as migrating status if create_export raises exception. In this case,
source volume can't be deleted even if it will be unnecessary.

This change fixes these two problems.

Closes-Bug: #1403916
Change-Id: Ie4199bc1e804e5cbbb793f448a99487f9823f1a9
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-02-16 20:10:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/3b4f2a7dfb47eebe5157cfd54ca6e9c45fff0634', 'message': "Clear migration_status from a destination volume if migration fails

properly even if volume migration is failed. If the migration is
in the migrating phase, the volume should be deleted and an entry
of database is also destroyed because the source volume is remaining.

Also there is an another problem that a source volume is remaining
as migrating status if create_export raises exception. In this case,
source volume can't be deleted even if it will be unnecessary.

This change fixes these two problems.

Closes-Bug: #1403916
Change-Id: Ie4199bc1e804e5cbbb793f448a99487f9823f1a9

commit_message:
Clear migration_status from a destination volume if migration fails

When some error happens during volume migration, cinder-volume
keeps remaining a destination volume because the volume copy may be
in the completing phase and a source volume may be deleted already.

In this case, the migration_status of the destination volume in
data base should be cleared. As a result, the volume can be handled
properly even if volume migration is failed. If the migration is
in the migrating phase, the volume should be deleted and an entry
of database is also destroyed because the source volume is remaining.

Also there is an another problem that a source volume is remaining
as migrating status if create_export raises exception. In this case,
source volume can't be deleted even if it will be unnecessary.

This change fixes these two problems.

Closes-Bug: #1403916
Change-Id: Ie4199bc1e804e5cbbb793f448a99487f9823f1a9

commit_message:
RBD: Query volume features from ceph.conf

This patch enabled RADOSClient to query the local ceph.conf for rbd
features configuration, falling back to layering if nothing is found.
This allows users to disable default features or to opt in to upcoming
features that have not yet become default.

Change-Id: I758e028abd703942ceb1c5b63c4b734817bc5df3

commit_message:
Changed filters to remove nova calls.

WIP - DO NOT MERGE

Remove the use of nova DB/API calls by the filters that require a host's
instance information to make their filtering decisions, as that
information is now contained in the host_state object.

Change-Id: I60604cc3235fa72c48810c0de562b169b116d518

commit_message:
Make compute update scheduler instance info.

WIP - DO NOT MERGE
This is proof-of-concept code, pending approval of the associated spec.

This patch adds the calls from compute to the scheduler client to pass
along the updated instance information for that compute node. It also
includes a new CONF setting to enable a deployment to disable sending
this information if they are not using any of the filters relating to
instances.

Change-Id: Iecfa26053a316b4eb79fe1447354da00e4db7dca

commit_message:
Remove transaction timestamp from container

The x-timestamp header is the timestamp of the transaction and
it is not directly related to the container.  If we want to
return transaction data, we should have some other way other than
making them attributes of the resource.

Change-Id: I473c48c5df01b7fdbf80029600892f7bfdbb31f9

commit_message:
RBD: remove non-layering support for antiquated versions

RBD layering was first included in Bobtail (Jan 2013) and all current
Cinder users are expected to have upgraded to a newer version by now.

This patch removes the logic necessary to accommodate Ceph versions that
predate Bobtail.

Change-Id: I335414868c0d0c8c5b15ca0aea9ab32bceeed6ac
